name: Acceptable Encryption Policy
content:
# Acceptable Encryption Policy

> **Free Use Disclaimer**: This policy was created by or for the SANS Institute for the Internet community. All or parts of this policy can be freely used for your organization. There is no prior approval required. If you would like to contribute a new policy or updated version of this policy, please send email to [policy-resources@sans.org](mailto:policy-resources@sans.org).  
> **Last Update Status**: Updated June 2014  
> © SANS Institute 2014 – All Rights Reserved

---

## 1. Overview

See [Purpose](#2-purpose).

---

## 2. Purpose

The purpose of this policy is to provide guidance that limits the use of encryption to those algorithms that have received substantial public review and have been proven to work effectively. Additionally, this policy provides direction to ensure that Federal regulations are followed, and legal authority is granted for the dissemination and use of encryption technologies outside of the United States.

---

## 3. Scope

This policy applies to all `<Company Name>` employees and affiliates.

> **Note**: Replace `<Company Name>` with your organization’s actual name when implementing this policy.

---

## 4. Policy

### 4.1 Algorithm Requirements

#### 4.1.1 Symmetric Encryption
Ciphers in use must meet or exceed the set defined as "AES-compatible" or "partially AES-compatible" according to the [IETF/IRTF Cipher Catalog](https://datatracker.ietf.org/wg/irtf-cfrg/about/), or the set defined for use in the United States National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) publication [FIPS 140-2](https://csrc.nist.gov/publications/detail/fips/140/2/final), or any superseding documents according to the date of implementation.  
**The use of the Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) is strongly recommended for symmetric encryption.**

#### 4.1.2 Asymmetric Encryption
Algorithms in use must meet the standards defined for use in NIST publication [FIPS 140-2](https://csrc.nist.gov/publications/detail/fips/140/2/final) or any superseding document, according to date of implementation.  
**The use of the RSA and Elliptic Curve Cryptography (ECC) algorithms is strongly recommended for asymmetric encryption.**

#### 4.1.3 Signature Algorithms

| Algorithm | Key Length (min) | Additional Comment |
|----------|------------------|--------------------|
| ECDSA P-256 | — | Consider [RFC 6090](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6090) to avoid patent infringement. |
| RSA | 2048 bits | Must use a secure padding scheme. PKCS#7 padding scheme is recommended. Message hashing required. |
| LDWM | SHA256 | Refer to [LDWM Hash-based Signatures Draft](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-mcgrew-hash-sigs) |

### 4.2 Hash Function Requirements

In general, `<Company Name>` adheres to the [NIST Policy on Hash Functions](https://csrc.nist.gov/projects/hash-functions).

### 4.3 Key Agreement and Authentication

- **4.3.1** Key exchanges must use one of the following cryptographic protocols:  
  - Diffie-Hellman  
  - IKE (Internet Key Exchange)  
  - Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman (ECDH)

- **4.3.2** Endpoints must be authenticated prior to the exchange or derivation of session keys.

- **4.3.3** Public keys used to establish trust must be authenticated prior to use. Examples of authentication include:
  - Transmission via cryptographically signed message
  - Manual verification of the public key hash

- **4.3.4** All servers used for authentication (e.g., RADIUS or TACACS) must have a valid certificate signed by a known trusted provider.

- **4.3.5** All servers and applications using SSL or TLS must have certificates signed by a known, trusted provider.

### 4.4 Key Generation

- **4.4.1** Cryptographic keys must be generated and stored in a secure manner that prevents loss, theft, or compromise.

- **4.4.2** Key generation must be seeded from an industry-standard Random Number Generator (RNG).  
  For examples, see **NIST Annex C: Approved Random Number Generators for FIPS PUB 140-2** ([link](https://csrc.nist.gov/publications/detail/fips/140/2/final)).

---

## 5. Policy Compliance

### 5.1 Compliance Measurement
The Infosec team will verify compliance to this policy through various methods, including but not limited to:
- Business tool reports  
- Internal and external audits  
- Feedback to the policy owner

### 5.2 Exceptions
Any exception to the policy must be approved by the Infosec team in advance.

### 5.3 Non-Compliance
An employee found to have violated this policy may be subject to disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment.

---

## 6. Related Standards, Policies and Processes

- [NIST FIPS 140-2](https://csrc.nist.gov/publications/detail/fips/140/2/final)  
- [NIST Policy on Hash Functions](https://csrc.nist.gov/projects/hash-functions)

---

## 7. Definitions and Terms

The following definitions and terms can be found in the **[SANS Glossary of Terms](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/)**:

- **Proprietary Encryption**

> Additional terms referenced in this policy (e.g., *Diffie-Hellman*, *Digital Signature*, *Cipher*, *Certificate-Based Authentication*) are also defined in the SANS Glossary.

---

## 8. Revision History

| Date of Change | Responsible        | Summary of Change                     |
|----------------|--------------------|----------------------------------------|
| June 2014      | SANS Policy Team   | Updated and converted to new format.   |

---

> **End of Document**

# Acceptable Use Policy (AUP)

> **Free Use Disclaimer**:  
> This policy was created by or for the **SANS Institute** for the Internet community. All or parts of this policy may be freely used by your organization without prior approval.  
> To contribute updates or new policies, email: **policy-resources@sans.org**  
> **Last Updated**: June 2014

---

## 1. Overview

Infosec’s intention in publishing this Acceptable Use Policy is not to impose restrictions contrary to `<Company Name>`’s culture of openness, trust, and integrity. Instead, it aims to protect `<Company Name>`’s employees, partners, and the company itself from illegal or damaging actions—whether intentional or accidental.

All Internet/Intranet/Extranet-related systems—including computer equipment, software, operating systems, storage media, email, web browsing, and FTP—are the **property of `<Company Name>`** and must be used primarily for **business purposes** in service of the company, its clients, and customers.

> Refer to Human Resources policies for additional guidance.

Effective security is a **shared responsibility**. Every employee and affiliate who handles information or uses information systems must understand and follow these guidelines.

---

## 2. Purpose

This policy defines the acceptable use of computing resources at `<Company Name>`. It exists to protect both employees and the organization from risks such as:
- Virus and malware infections  
- Network or system compromise  
- Legal liability and regulatory violations  

---

## 3. Scope

This policy applies to:
- All information, electronic devices, and network resources used to conduct `<Company Name>` business  
- Devices **owned, leased, or personally owned** (when used for company purposes)  

It covers **all employees, contractors, consultants, temporary staff, and third-party personnel** affiliated with `<Company Name>` or its subsidiaries.

All users must exercise sound judgment in accordance with company policies, standards, and applicable laws.

> Exceptions require prior approval (see Section 5.2).

---

## 4. Policy

### 4.1 General Use and Ownership

4.1.1 **Proprietary information** stored on any device—whether company-owned, personal, or third-party—remains the sole property of `<Company Name>`. You must protect it per the **Data Protection Standard**.

4.1.2 Report **loss, theft, or unauthorized disclosure** of company data **immediately**.

4.1.3 Access or share company data **only when authorized and necessary** for your job duties.

4.1.4 **Personal use** of company systems must be reasonable and infrequent. Departments may issue specific guidelines; otherwise, consult your manager if uncertain.

4.1.5 Authorized personnel may **monitor systems and network traffic** at any time for security and maintenance (per the Audit Policy).

4.1.6 `<Company Name>` reserves the right to **audit systems periodically** to ensure compliance.

---

### 4.2 Security and Proprietary Information

4.2.1 All devices connecting to the internal network must comply with the **Minimum Access Policy**.

4.2.2 Passwords must follow the **Password Policy**. **Sharing accounts or passwords is prohibited**.

4.2.3 All devices must use a **password-protected screensaver** that activates within **10 minutes or less**. **Lock or log off** when unattended.

4.2.4 Posts from a `<Company Name>` email address to newsgroups must include:  
> *“Opinions expressed are my own and not necessarily those of `<Company Name>`.”*  
(Unless posted as part of official duties.)

4.2.5 Exercise **extreme caution** with email attachments from unknown senders—they may contain **malware**.

> 🔍 **Crimeware**: A type of malware used by cybercriminals to monetize infected systems (e.g., keyloggers, botnets for DDoS).  
> *(Source: [SANS Glossary](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/))*

---

### 4.3 Unacceptable Use

The following activities are **prohibited**, except when required for legitimate job functions (e.g., system administration).

> **No employee may use company resources for any activity illegal under local, state, federal, or international law.**

#### 4.3.1 System and Network Activities (Strictly Prohibited)

1. **Copyright/trade secret violations** (e.g., using unlicensed or “pirated” software).  
2. Unauthorized copying/distribution of copyrighted material (music, images, books, software).  
3. Accessing data, servers, or accounts **outside business purposes**, even with valid access.  
4. **Export control violations** (e.g., exporting encryption tech without authorization).  
5. Introducing **malicious programs** (viruses, worms, Trojan horses, email bombs).  
6. Sharing your password or allowing others (including family) to use your account.  
7. Transmitting content that violates **sexual harassment** or **hostile workplace** laws.  
8. Making **fraudulent offers** from a company account.  
9. Issuing unauthorized **warranty statements**.  
10. Causing **security breaches or disruptions**, such as:
    - Accessing data not intended for you  
    - Logging into unauthorized systems  
    - **Network sniffing**, **ping floods**, **packet spoofing**, **denial of service (DoS)**, forged routing  
11. Performing **port scanning** or **security scanning** without **prior notice to Infosec**.  
12. Intercepting network data not intended for your host (unless part of your job).  
13. **Circumventing authentication** or security controls.  
14. Deploying **honeypots** or **honeynets** on the company network.  
15. **Denying service** to other users (e.g., DoS attacks).  
16. Disabling or interfering with another user’s terminal session.  
17. Disclosing **employee information** to external parties.

> 🔍 Definitions:  
> - **Honeypot**: A decoy system designed to attract and trap attackers.  
> - **Honeynet**: A network of honeypots used for monitoring attacker behavior.  
> *(Source: [SANS Glossary](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/))*

#### 4.3.2 Email and Communication Activities

When representing the company online, always clarify:  
> *“Views are my own.”*

Prohibited:
1. Sending **unsolicited bulk email** (**spam**).  
2. **Harassment** via email, phone, or messaging (by language, frequency, or volume).  
3. **Forging email headers**.  
4. Soliciting replies to a third-party address to harass or collect responses.  
5. Forwarding **chain letters**, **Ponzi schemes**, or **pyramid schemes**.  
6. Using company systems to send spam on behalf of external services.  
7. **Newsgroup spam** (posting identical non-business messages to many groups).

> 🔍 **Spam**: Unsolicited bulk electronic messages, typically sent for advertising or phishing.  
> *(Source: [SANS Glossary](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/))*

#### 4.3.3 Blogging and Social Media

1. Limited, occasional blogging on company systems is allowed if:
   - Professional and responsible  
   - Compliant with all policies  
   - Not detrimental to `<Company Name>`  
   - Does not interfere with work  
   > ⚠️ Subject to monitoring.

2. **Never disclose** confidential, proprietary, or trade secret information.

> 🔍 **Proprietary Information**: Information owned by an organization that is not publicly known and provides a competitive advantage.  
> *(Source: [SANS Glossary](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/))*

3. Do not post content that harms `<Company Name>`’s reputation or violates anti-harassment policies.

4. **Do not attribute personal opinions** to `<Company Name>`. Clearly state you are speaking as an individual.

5. **Do not use** company trademarks, logos, or intellectual property in personal blogs.

> 🔍 **Blogging**: Publishing regular entries of commentary, events, or other content on a website.  
> *(Source: [SANS Glossary](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/))*

---

## 5. Policy Compliance

### 5.1 Compliance Measurement  
Verified via:
- Business tool reports  
- Internal/external audits  
- Feedback mechanisms  

### 5.2 Exceptions  
Require **advance written approval** from the Infosec team.

### 5.3 Non-Compliance  
May result in **disciplinary action**, up to and including **termination**.

---

## 6. Related Policies

- Data Classification Policy  
- Data Protection Standard  
- Social Media Policy  
- Minimum Access Policy  
- Password Policy  

---

## 7. Key Definitions (from SANS Glossary)

| Term | Definition |
|------|-----------|
| **Blogging** | Publishing regular entries of commentary, descriptions of events, or other content on a website. |
| **Honeypot** | A decoy system designed to attract and trap attackers. |
| **Honeynet** | A network of honeypots used for monitoring attacker behavior. |
| **Proprietary Information** | Information owned by an organization that is not publicly known and provides a competitive advantage. |
| **Spam** | Unsolicited bulk electronic messages. |
| **Crimeware** | Malware used by cybercriminals to monetize infected systems (e.g., keyloggers, botnets). |

> Full glossary: [SANS Security Glossary of Terms](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/)

---

# Acquisition Assessment Policy

> **Free Use Disclaimer**:  
> This policy was created by or for the **SANS Institute** for the Internet community. All or parts of this policy may be freely used by your organization without prior approval.  
> To contribute updates or new policies, email: **policy-resources@sans.org**  
> **Last Updated**: June 2014

---

## 1. Overview

Integrating a newly acquired company can significantly impact the security posture of both the parent (`<Company Name>`) and the acquired entity. Differences in network architecture, security controls, and organizational culture may introduce substantial risk.

The goals of the security acquisition assessment and integration process are to:

- Assess the acquired company’s security landscape, posture, and policies  
- Protect both `<Company Name>` and the acquired company from increased security risks  
- Educate the acquired company on `<Company Name>` policies and standards  
- Adopt and implement `<Company Name>` Security Policies and Standards  
- Fully integrate the acquired company into the corporate environment  
- Ensure **continuous monitoring and auditing** post-acquisition  

---

## 2. Purpose

This policy establishes **Infosec responsibilities** during corporate acquisitions and defines the **minimum security requirements** for an Infosec acquisition assessment.

---

## 3. Scope

Applies to:
- All companies acquired by `<Company Name>`  
- All systems, networks, labs, test equipment, hardware, software, and firmware owned or operated by the acquired company  

---

## 4. Policy

### 4.1 General

Acquisition assessments ensure that an acquired company **does not introduce security risks** to `<Company Name>`’s networks, systems, or sensitive data.

The **Infosec Team** will:
- Participate as active members of the acquisition team throughout the process  
- Identify and evaluate information security risks  
- Develop remediation plans with stakeholders  
- Work with the acquisitions team to implement risk mitigations **before** any network connectivity is permitted  

> **No acquired systems may connect to `<Company Name>` networks until security requirements are met or formally waived.**

### 4.2 Requirements

#### 4.2.1 Hosts
- **4.2.1.1** All hosts (servers, desktops, laptops) must either:
  - Be **replaced or re-imaged** with a `<Company Name>` standard image, **or**  
  - Comply with `<Company Name>`’s **minimum end-user device standards**  
- **4.2.1.2** Business-critical production servers that cannot be re-imaged must undergo a **security audit** and receive a **waiver from Infosec**  
- **4.2.1.3** All PC-based hosts must have **`<Company Name>`-approved antivirus software** installed **before** network connection

> 🔍 **Business Critical Production Server**: A server essential to core business operations whose failure would result in significant operational, financial, or reputational impact.  
> *(Source: [SANS Glossary](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/))*

#### 4.2.2 Networks
- **4.2.2.1** All network devices (routers, switches, firewalls) must be **replaced or re-imaged** with a `<Company Name>` standard configuration  
- **4.2.2.2** Wireless access points must be configured to `<Company Name>` security standards  

#### 4.2.3 Internet
- **4.2.3.1** All existing Internet connections of the acquired company **must be terminated**  
- **4.2.3.2** If a business-justified **air-gapped Internet connection** is required, it must undergo **Infosec review and approval**

#### 4.2.4 Remote Access
- **4.2.4.1** All existing remote access solutions (e.g., VPNs, RDP gateways) **must be disabled**  
- **4.2.4.2** Remote access to the production network will be provided exclusively by `<Company Name>`  

#### 4.2.5 Labs
- **4.2.5.1** Lab equipment must be **physically secured and separated** from non-lab areas  
- **4.2.5.2** The lab network must be **firewalled** from the corporate production network  
- **4.2.5.3** Any direct external connections (analog, ISDN, T1, etc.) to customers or partners require **review and approval by the Lab Security Group (LabSec)**  
- **4.2.5.4** All acquired labs must comply with **LabSec policy** or obtain a **waiver from LabSec**  
- **4.2.5.5** If acquired systems **fail to meet these requirements**, the **`<Company Name>` Chief Information Officer (CIO)** must **formally acknowledge and approve** the associated risk before network integration

---

## 5. Policy Compliance

### 5.1 Compliance Measurement  
The Infosec team verifies compliance through:
- Business tool reports  
- Internal and external audits  
- Feedback to the policy owner  

### 5.2 Exceptions  
All exceptions require **advance written approval** from the Infosec team.

### 5.3 Non-Compliance  
Violations may result in **disciplinary action**, up to and including **termination of employment**.

---

## 6. Related Standards, Policies and Processes

_None._

---

## 7. Definitions and Terms

The following term is defined in the **[SANS Glossary of Terms](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/)**:

- **Business Critical Production Server**

name: Analog ISDN Line Security Policy
content:
# Analog/ISDN Line Security Policy

> **Free Use Disclaimer**:  
> This policy was created by or for the **SANS Institute** for the Internet community. All or parts of this policy may be freely used by your organization without prior approval.  
> To contribute updates or new policies, email: **policy-resources@sans.org**  
> **Status**: Retired  
> **Last Updated**: December 2013

---

## 1. Overview

See **Purpose**.

---

## 2. Purpose

This policy defines the acceptable use, approval requirements, and security procedures for **analog and ISDN lines** at `<Company Name>`. It covers two distinct use cases:
- Lines used **exclusively for fax transmission/reception**  
- Lines **connected to computers or intelligent devices**

---

## 3. Scope

This policy applies **only** to analog/ISDN lines connected **inside `<Company Name>` buildings or testing sites**.

It **does not apply** to:
- Lines connected to **employee homes**  
- **PBX desktop phones**  
- Lines used by **Telecom for emergency or non-corporate purposes**

---

## 4. Policy

### 4.1 Security Scenarios & Business Impact

Two primary threat scenarios justify this policy:

1. **External Attack via Modem**:  
   An attacker dials analog numbers hoping to reach a computer with an **auto-answering modem**. If successful, they may:
   - Bypass network monitoring  
   - Compromise internal systems  
   - Steal sensitive corporate data (potentially worth millions)

2. **Internal Physical Access + Data Exfiltration**:  
   An intruder with physical access uses a **modem-equipped computer** to:
   - Connect to `<Company Name>`’s trusted network via Ethernet  
   - Dial out via modem to an external site  
   - **Exfiltrate data** to an unmonitored location

These risks necessitate strict controls on analog/ISDN line usage.

---

### 4.2 Facsimile (Fax) Machines

#### General Rules:
- Fax lines are approved **for departmental use only**  
- **No personal fax lines** permitted  
- **No analog lines in personal cubicles**  
- Fax machines must be placed in a **centralized administrative area**, **away from computer equipment**  
- **Computers must not be used as fax devices** over analog lines

> **Waivers** may be granted case-by-case based on business need, data sensitivity, and security posture.

#### Conditions for Use:
If approved, the authorized user **must** ensure:
- The line is used **only as specified in the request**  
- **Only authorized personnel** have access  
- When **not in use**, the line is **physically disconnected** from the computer  
- When **in use**, the computer is **disconnected from `<Company Name>`’s internal network**  
- Use is **strictly for company business** (no personal use)  
- All downloaded material is **scanned with an approved, up-to-date antivirus utility** (e.g., McAfee VirusScan) before introduction to company systems

---

### 4.3 Computer-to-Analog/ISDN Line Connections

- **General Rule**: **No approval** will be granted to connect computers or intelligent devices to analog/ISDN lines due to **significant security risks**.  
- **Waivers** are considered **only on a case-by-case basis**.  
- **Replacement lines** (e.g., after a move) are treated as **new requests** and subject to the same review.

> ⚠️ Active attacks against such lines have been documented in the wild.

---

### 4.4 Requesting an Analog/ISDN Line

After **manager approval**, the requester must submit the following to **Telecom**:

#### Required Information:
- A **detailed business case** explaining why secure alternatives (e.g., corporate Internet, dial-out pools) cannot be used  
- The **business purpose** of the line  
- **Hardware and software** to be connected  
- **External systems** the line will access  

#### Business Case Must Address:
- What business function requires this line?  
- Why can’t a standard `<Company Name>` desktop with Internet fulfill this need?  
- Why can’t the existing corporate **dial-out access pool** be used?

#### Security Profile Questions (Must Be Answered):
- Will the machine be **physically disconnected** from the internal network when using the line?  
- Where will the line be installed? (Cubicle? Lab?)  
- Is **dial-in access from outside** required?  
- How many lines/users? Frequency of use?  
- What is the **earliest termination date**? (Line must be disconnected when no longer needed)  
- What **additional controls** prevent unauthorized use?  
- If a replacement line: What was the **original purpose**?  
- What **protocols** will run over the line?  
- Will an **approved antivirus scanner** be installed and maintained?

> 📝 **All requests must use the official _Analog/ISDN Line Request Form_**.

---

## 5. Policy Compliance

### 5.1 Compliance Measurement  
The Infosec team verifies compliance through:
- Business tool reports  
- Internal and external audits  
- Feedback to the policy owner  

### 5.2 Exceptions  
All exceptions require **advance written approval** from the Infosec team.

### 5.3 Non-Compliance  
Violations may result in **disciplinary action**, up to and including **termination of employment**.

---

# Anti-Virus Guidelines

> **Free Use Disclaimer**:  
> This policy was created by or for the **SANS Institute** for the Internet community. All or parts of this policy may be freely used by your organization without prior approval.  
> To contribute updates or new policies, email: **policy-resources@sans.org**  
> **Status**: Retired  
> **Last Updated**: December 2013

---

## Overview

These guidelines provide recommended practices to help prevent virus infections and limit their impact across `<Company Name>` systems and networks. While retired, they remain useful as foundational hygiene practices in endpoint security.

---

## Recommended Anti-Virus Practices

To reduce the risk of malware infection, all users **must** follow these procedures:

- ✅ **Use corporate-standard anti-virus software**:  
  Always run the **approved, supported anti-virus solution** available from the corporate download site. Keep both the software and its virus definitions **up to date**.

- 🚫 **Never open email attachments from unknown or suspicious sources**:  
  Delete such messages **immediately**, and **empty your Trash/Recycle Bin** (“double delete”) to ensure permanent removal.

- 🗑️ **Do not forward spam, chain letters, or junk email**:  
  Delete these messages in accordance with `<Company Name>`’s **Acceptable Use Policy**.

- 🌐 **Avoid downloading files from untrusted websites or sources**:  
  Only download software or data from verified, legitimate sources.

- 💾 **Limit direct disk sharing with read/write access**:  
  Enable shared drives or folders with write permissions **only when absolutely required for business purposes**.

- 📼 **Scan external media before use**:  
  Always scan floppy disks, USB drives, or other removable media from **unknown sources** for viruses before opening any files.

- 💾 **Back up critical data regularly**:  
  Maintain frequent backups of important files and system configurations, and store them in a **secure, offline location**.

- 🧪 **Lab testing exception**:  
  If anti-virus software interferes with lab testing:
  1. Run a full scan to confirm the system is clean  
  2. **Temporarily disable** the anti-virus software  
  3. Perform the lab test  
  4. **Re-enable** anti-virus protection immediately after  
  > ⚠️ While disabled, **do not use email, web browsers, file sharing, or any network-connected applications** that could introduce malware.

- 🔁 **Stay informed**:  
  New viruses emerge daily. **Periodically review** the Lab Anti-Virus Policy and this guideline list for updates—even though this document is retired, the principles remain relevant.

---

content:
# Automatically Forwarded Email Policy

> **Free Use Disclaimer**:  
> This policy was created by or for the **SANS Institute** for the Internet community. All or parts of this policy may be freely used by your organization without prior approval.  
> To contribute updates or new policies, email: **policy-resources@sans.org**  
> **Status**: Retired  
> **Last Updated**: July 2014

---

## 1. Overview

See **Purpose**.

---

## 2. Purpose

To prevent the **unauthorized or inadvertent disclosure of sensitive company information** through automatic email forwarding.

---

## 3. Scope

This policy applies to:
- All **employees**, **vendors**, and **agents** acting on behalf of `<Company Name>`  
- Any configuration that enables **automatic forwarding** of `<Company Name>` email to external destinations  

---

## 4. Policy

- Employees must exercise **utmost caution** when sending email from `<Company Name>` systems to external networks.  
- **Automatic forwarding** of `<Company Name>` email to **external destinations is prohibited**, unless **explicitly approved** by the employee’s manager **and** Infosec.  
- **Sensitive Information** (as defined in the **Data Classification and Protection Policy**) **must not be forwarded** via email unless:
  - The communication is **critical to business operations**, **and**

> - **Forwarded Email**: An email message that is automatically or manually sent from one recipient to another.  
> - **Sensitive Information**: Data that must be protected from unauthorized access to safeguard the privacy or security of an individual or organization.  
> - **Unauthorized Disclosure**: The release of information to parties not approved to receive it.

## 1. Overview

Bluetooth-enabled devices are proliferating rapidly, and their connectivity range has increased significantly. Insecure Bluetooth configurations can introduce serious security risks—including data interception, device spoofing, and unauthorized access. This policy establishes a **minimum security baseline** to mitigate these threats.

---

## 2. Purpose

To define the **minimum baseline standards** for connecting Bluetooth-enabled devices to `<Company Name>` networks or company-owned equipment, ensuring adequate protection of:
- **Personally Identifiable Information (PII)**  
- **Confidential and sensitive `<Company Name>` data**

---

## 3. Scope

Applies to **all Bluetooth-enabled devices** that:
- Connect to `<Company Name>` networks, **or**  
- Interface with `<Company Name>`-owned devices  

This includes employee-owned, contractor-provided, and company-issued devices used in a business context.

---

## 4. Policy

### 4.1 Bluetooth Version
- **No Bluetooth device** may be deployed on `<Company Name>` equipment unless it supports **Bluetooth v2.1 or higher**.  
- Devices purchased **before this policy’s effective date** are exempt from the version requirement but **must comply with all other provisions** of this policy.  
- Exceptions require **written authorization from the Infosec Team**.

### 4.2 PINs and Pairing
- Perform initial pairing **only in private, secure locations** to prevent PIN exposure.  
- If a **previously paired device prompts for a PIN again**, **do not accept** the pairing request.  
  > 🚨 **Immediately report** such incidents to Infosec via the Help Desk—this may indicate a **Bluejacking**, **Bluesnarfing**, or **man-in-the-middle attack**.

### 4.3 Device Security Settings
All Bluetooth devices **must** be configured as follows:
- ✅ Use **Security Mode 3** (enforces **encryption in both directions**)  
- ✅ Set a **minimum PIN length of 8 characters** (longer = stronger)  
- ✅ Enable **non-discoverable (hidden) mode** when not actively pairing  
- ✅ **Activate Bluetooth only when needed**—disable when idle  
- ✅ Keep **device firmware updated** to the latest vendor-recommended version

### 4.4 Security Audits
- The Infosec Team may conduct **random compliance audits**.  
- During audits, team members **will not eavesdrop on voice conversations** or access user data beyond what is necessary to verify policy adherence.

### 4.5 Unauthorized Use
The following activities are **strictly prohibited**:
- Eavesdropping on, spoofing, or launching **DoS attacks** against other Bluetooth devices  
- Using `<Company Name>`-owned Bluetooth equipment with **non-company devices**  
- **Modifying** Bluetooth devices (hardware or software) without authorization

### 4.6 User Responsibilities
Bluetooth users **must**:
- Comply with all requirements in this policy  
- **Turn off Bluetooth** when not in use  
- **Never transmit or store** PII, confidential, or sensitive `<Company Name>` data on Bluetooth-enabled devices  
- Access company systems **only via approved** Bluetooth hardware, software, and connections  
- Ensure all Bluetooth solutions **meet this policy’s standards** before deployment  
- **Protect** information, network access, passwords, cryptographic keys, and devices  
- **Immediately report** any:
  - Misuse  
  - Loss  
  - Theft  
  of Bluetooth devices or systems to Infosec

# Clean Desk Policy

> **Free Use Disclaimer**:  
> This policy was created by or for the **SANS Institute** for the Internet community. All or parts of this policy may be freely used by your organization without prior approval.  
> To contribute updates or new policies, email: **policy-resources@sans.org**  
> **Last Updated**: June 2014

---

## 1. Overview

A Clean Desk Policy is a critical physical security control that helps ensure all **sensitive or confidential materials**—whether physical or digital—are **secured and out of sight** when not in use or when an employee leaves their workstation.  

This policy:
- Reduces the risk of **unauthorized access**, **data theft**, and **security breaches**  
- Increases employee **awareness of information protection responsibilities**  
- Supports compliance with standards such as **ISO/IEC 27001** and **ISO/IEC 27002 (formerly 17799)**  

---

## 2. Purpose

To establish **minimum requirements** for maintaining a “clean desk” environment where sensitive information—including data about employees, intellectual property, customers, and vendors—is **securely stored** and **not visible** to unauthorized individuals.

---

## 3. Scope

Applies to **all `<Company Name>` employees and affiliates**, including contractors, consultants, and temporary staff, regardless of work location (office, remote, or hybrid).

---

## 4. Policy Requirements

All personnel **must** comply with the following:

- **4.1** Secure all **sensitive/confidential information** (hardcopy or electronic) in locked storage at the **end of each workday** and whenever **away for an extended period**.  
- **4.2** **Lock computer workstations** whenever the workspace is unoccupied—even briefly.  
- **4.3** **Shut down computers completely** at the end of the workday (unless business continuity requires otherwise with Infosec approval).  
- **4.4** Remove all **Restricted or Sensitive information** from desks and **lock it in a drawer** when unattended or at day’s end.  
- **4.5** Keep **file cabinets containing sensitive data closed and locked** when not in active use or unattended.  
- **4.6** **Never leave keys** to locked drawers, cabinets, or offices **on or near an unattended desk**.  
- **4.7** **Secure laptops** using a **locking cable** or store them in a **locked drawer or cabinet**.  
- **4.8** **Do not write down passwords** on sticky notes, paper, or in unsecured digital files. Passwords must **never be visible** on or under devices.  
- **4.9** **Immediately retrieve printouts** containing Restricted or Sensitive information from printers.  
- **4.10** Dispose of sensitive documents only in **official shredder bins** or **locked confidential disposal bins**—**never in regular trash**.  
- **4.11** **Erase whiteboards** that display Restricted or Sensitive information when no longer needed.  
- **4.12** **Lock away portable computing devices** (e.g., laptops, tablets) when not in use.  
- **4.13** Treat **removable media** (USB drives, CDs, DVDs) as sensitive and store them in **locked drawers**.  

> 🖨️ **Additional Guidance**:  
> All printers and fax machines must be **cleared of output immediately** to prevent unauthorized access to sensitive documents left in output trays.

---

## 1. Overview

This policy establishes security configuration requirements for all communication equipment integrated into `<Company Name>`’s data network to protect against unauthorized access, data interception, and system compromise.

---

## 2. Purpose

To define the minimum security standards for the configuration, access control, and monitoring of **communication equipment** (e.g., routers, switches, firewalls, gateways) used within `<Company Name>`.

---

## 3. Scope

Applies to **all communication equipment** that is part of `<Company Name>`’s **data network infrastructure**, regardless of vendor, location, or ownership.

---

## 4. Policy

### 4.1 Security Configuration & Role-Based Access
- All required **security features must be enabled** before equipment is placed into service.  
- Only two user roles are permitted:
  - **Monitoring**: Read-only access  
  - **Administrator**: Full configuration privileges  
- **All user commands and security-relevant events** must be **logged** for audit and incident response.

### 4.2 Centralized Authentication
- **Local user accounts are prohibited** on communication equipment.  
- All users **must authenticate** through a **central user repository** (e.g., RADIUS, TACACS+, LDAP) using a protocol that **minimizes identity theft risk** (e.g., avoiding plaintext protocols like Telnet).

### 4.3 Encrypted Communications
- **All data transmitted** from the device (e.g., management traffic, logs, configuration backups) **must be encrypted** using a **strong encryption algorithm** to prevent:
  - **Eavesdropping**  
  - **Man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks**

> 🔍 **Key Definitions** (from [SANS Glossary](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/)):  
> - **Eavesdropping**: Unauthorized interception of data transmitted over a network.  
> - **Man-in-the-middle Attack**: An attack where the attacker secretly relays and possibly alters communication between two parties who believe they are directly communicating with each other.  
> - **Strong Encryption**: Cryptographic methods that are computationally infeasible to break with current technology (e.g., AES-256, TLS 1.2+).

### 4.4 Log Retention & Integrity
- **Event logs** must be stored on media included in the organization’s **regular backup process**.  
- Backup procedures **must preserve log integrity**—logs **must not be altered or tampered with**.

### 4.5 Administrator Password Management
- The **local administrator password** must **not be known** by any operational staff.  
- If emergency access is required:
  1. Submit a formal request to the **Internal Security Division**  
  2. Include **business justification** and complete required forms  
  3. After use, the password **must be immediately reset** by the highest-level administrator  

> This ensures **break-glass** access is **auditable, justified, and temporary**.

content:
# Data Breach Response Policy

> **Free Use Disclaimer**: Created by or for the SANS Institute. Feel free to modify or use for your organization. If you have a policy to contribute, please send email to [stephen@sans.edu](mailto:stephen@sans.edu).  
> **Last Updated**: August 17, 2016  
> © SANS Institute 2016 – All Rights Reserved

---

## 1.0 Purpose

The purpose of this policy is to establish the goals and vision for the breach response process. This policy clearly defines:

- To whom it applies  
- Under what circumstances it is triggered  
- The definition of a **data breach**  
- Staff roles and responsibilities  
- Standards and metrics (e.g., for incident prioritization)  
- Reporting, remediation, and feedback mechanisms  

This policy shall be well-publicized and made easily accessible to all personnel whose duties involve data privacy and security protection.

`<ORGANIZATION NAME>` Information Security publishes this Data Breach Response Policy to emphasize the critical importance of data security and to guide how the organization’s established culture of **openness, trust, and integrity** should respond to security incidents. `<ORGANIZATION NAME>` is committed to protecting its employees, partners, and the organization itself from illegal or damaging actions—whether intentional or accidental.

> **Note**: Replace `<ORGANIZATION NAME>` with your actual organization name when implementing.

---

## 1.1 Background

Any individual who suspects the **theft, breach, or exposure** of `<ORGANIZATION NAME>` **Protected Data** or **Sensitive Data** must **immediately report** the incident via one of the following methods:

- Email: [Helpdesk@<ORGANIZATION NAME>.org](mailto:Helpdesk@<ORGANIZATION NAME>.org)  
- Phone: **555-1212**  
- Web Form: [http://<ORGANIZATION NAME>](http://<ORGANIZATION NAME>)

These channels are monitored by the **Information Security Administrator**, who will investigate all reports to confirm whether a breach occurred. If confirmed, the appropriate incident response procedure will be initiated.

---

## 2.0 Scope

This policy applies to **all individuals** who:

- Collect, access, maintain, distribute, process, protect, store, use, transmit, or dispose of  
- **Personally Identifiable Information (PII)** or **Protected Health Information (PHI)**  
- Related to `<ORGANIZATION NAME>` members, employees, partners, or clients

All vendor agreements must include contractual language that ensures equivalent protection of `<ORGANIZATION NAME>` data.

> 🔗 **Definitions**:  
> - [Personally Identifiable Information (PII)](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/#personally-identifiable-information-pii)  
> - [Protected Health Information (PHI)](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/#protected-health-information-phi)

---

## 3.0 Policy

### 3.1 Confirmed Breach Response

Upon confirmation of a **theft, breach, or exposure** involving `<ORGANIZATION NAME>` **Protected** or **Sensitive Data**:

1. **Immediate Containment**: All access to the affected system or data resource will be revoked.
2. **Incident Response Team Activation**: The **Executive Director** will chair an Incident Response Team (IRT).

#### Incident Response Team Composition
The IRT will include representatives from:
- IT Infrastructure  
- IT Applications / Application Security  
- Legal  
- Communications  
- Human Resources  
- Finance (if financial data is involved)  
- Member Services (if member data is affected)  
- The affected department or unit  
- Additional experts as deemed necessary by the Executive Director

### 3.2 Forensic Investigation

- `<ORGANIZATION NAME>`’s cyber insurance provider will engage **qualified forensic investigators**.
- The forensic team will determine:
  - How the breach occurred  
  - Types of data compromised  
  - Number of individuals or organizations impacted (internal/external)  
  - Root cause of the incident

### 3.3 Communication Plan

In coordination with **Communications, Legal, and HR**, the IRT will develop a communication strategy to notify:
- **Internal employees**  
- **Affected individuals** (e.g., members, patients, customers)  
- **Regulatory bodies** (as required by law, e.g., HIPAA, GDPR, CCPA)  
- **The public**, if necessary

All external communications must be pre-approved by Legal and Executive Leadership.

---

## 3.4 Ownership and Responsibilities

| Role | Responsibility |
|------|----------------|
| **Sponsors** | Individuals (typically executives or data owners) responsible for maintaining specific information resources. They are accountable for data classification and protection. |
| **Information Security Administrator** | Designated by the Executive Director or IT Infrastructure Director. Oversees implementation, coordination, and enforcement of security procedures in consultation with Sponsors. |
| **Users** | All authorized individuals accessing `<ORGANIZATION NAME>` systems—including staff, contractors, interns, volunteers, and third parties. Must comply with this policy. |
| **Incident Response Team (IRT)** | Chaired by Executive Management. Includes cross-functional representatives to manage breach response, remediation, and communication. |

> 🔗 **Related Terms**:  
> - [Information Resource](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/#information-resource)  
> - [Safeguards](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/#safeguards)

---

## 4.0 Enforcement

Violations of this policy may result in:

- **For employees**: Disciplinary action up to and including **termination of employment**  
- **For third parties**: Immediate **termination of network access** and potential legal action

Compliance is mandatory for all personnel and partners handling `<ORGANIZATION NAME>` data.

---

## 5.0 Definitions

| Term | Definition |
|------|-----------|
| **Encryption / Encrypted Data** | The most effective method to achieve data security. Requires a secret key or password to decrypt. |
| **Plain Text** | Unencrypted data. |
| **Hacker** | A slang term for a computer enthusiast or expert in programming and systems. *(Note: Not inherently malicious)* |
| **Protected Health Information (PHI)** | Under U.S. law, any health-related information that can be linked to an individual and is created or collected by a Covered Entity or its Business Associate. |
| **Personally Identifiable Information (PII)** | Any data that can identify a specific individual (e.g., name, SSN, email, IP address). |
| **Protected Data** | Encompasses PII and PHI. |
| **Sensitive Data** | Data (encrypted or plain text) containing PII or PHI. |
| **Information Resource** | The data and information assets owned or managed by an organization, department, or unit. |
| **Safeguards** | Controls or countermeasures designed to avoid, detect, or minimize security risks to assets. |

> All definitions align with the **[SANS Glossary of Terms](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/)**.

---

content:
# Database Credentials Coding Policy

> **Free Use Disclaimer**: This policy was created by or for the SANS Institute for the Internet community. All or parts of this policy can be freely used for your organization. There is no prior approval required. If you would like to contribute a new policy or updated version of this policy, please send email to [policy-resources@sans.org](mailto:policy-resources@sans.org).  
> **Last Update Status**: Updated June 2014  
> © SANS Institute 2014 – All Rights Reserved

---

## 1. Overview

Database authentication credentials are a necessary part of authorizing applications to connect to internal databases. However, **incorrect use, storage, or transmission** of such credentials could lead to the compromise of highly sensitive assets and serve as a springboard for broader organizational compromise.

---

## 2. Purpose

This policy establishes requirements for the **secure storage and retrieval** of database usernames and passwords (i.e., **database credentials**) used by software programs to access databases on `<Company Name>`’s networks.

Applications running on `<Company Name>` networks often require access to internal database servers. To authenticate, these programs must present valid credentials. If credentials are stored insecurely (e.g., in source code), they may be exposed—leading to unauthorized database access and potential data breaches.

> **Note**: Replace `<Company Name>` with your actual organization name when implementing.

---

## 3. Scope

This policy applies to:

- All **system implementers**, **software engineers**, and **developers**  
- Any **software** (programs, modules, libraries, or APIs) that accesses a `<Company Name>` **multi-user production database**

> **Recommendation**: Apply these same requirements to **non-production** and **local development** environments, as they often contain unsanitized or real data.

---

## 4. Policy

### General Requirements

To maintain the security of `<Company Name>`’s internal databases:

- Database credentials **must not** be stored in the **main executing body of source code** in **clear text**.  
- Database credentials **must not** be stored in any location **accessible via a web server** (e.g., document root, public directories).

---

### Specific Requirements

#### **Storage of Database Usernames and Passwords**

- ✅ Credentials **may** be stored in a **separate file** from the application code.  
  - This file **must not be world-readable or world-writable** (e.g., permissions should be `600` on Unix-like systems).
- ✅ Credentials **may** reside on the **database server itself**.  
  - In this case, only a **hash identifier** (not the password) may be stored in code.
- ✅ Credentials **may** be managed by an **authentication server** (e.g., LDAP, entitlement directory).  
  - The application authenticates via the user’s session, eliminating the need for embedded credentials.
- ❌ Credentials **must not** reside in the **web server’s document tree** (e.g., `/var/www`, `htdocs`).
- ❌ **Pass-through authentication** (e.g., Oracle OPS$) **must not** grant database access based solely on remote host authentication.
- 🔒 All database passwords **must comply** with the organization’s **[Password Policy](#6-related-standards-policies-and-processes)**.

#### **Retrieval of Database Credentials**

- Credentials stored in external files must be:
  - Read **immediately before use**
  - **Cleared from memory** immediately after authentication (e.g., zero out buffers)
- Credential storage must be **physically and logically separated** from application logic:
  - Store credentials in a **dedicated source file**
  - This file must contain **only credentials and accessor methods**—no other business logic
- For interpreted languages (e.g., Python, Perl, PHP):
  - The credential file **must not** reside in the same **browseable or executable directory tree** as the main application

#### **Access Control for Credentials**

- Each program or group of programs implementing a **single business function** must use **unique database credentials**.  
  - **Credential sharing between applications is prohibited**.
- Database passwords used by programs are considered **system-level passwords** per the Password Policy.
- Development teams must implement a **formal process** to:
  - Rotate passwords per policy
  - Restrict knowledge of credentials to **need-to-know personnel only**

---

### Coding Techniques

> 📌 **Implementation Guidance**:  
> Refer to your organization’s **language-specific secure coding standards** for:
> - Java (e.g., use of `javax.crypto` and external property files)
> - C/C++ (e.g., secure memory handling with `memset_s`)
> - Python (e.g., environment variables or vault integration)
> - Perl, .NET, Node.js, etc.

> Example integrations: HashiCorp Vault, AWS Secrets Manager, Azure Key Vault, or encrypted config files with strict ACLs.

---

## 5. Policy Compliance

### 5.1 Compliance Measurement  
The Infosec team will verify compliance through:
- Static and dynamic code analysis tools  
- Internal/external security audits  
- Peer code reviews  
- Feedback to the policy owner

### 5.2 Exceptions  
All exceptions require **prior written approval** from the Infosec team.

### 5.3 Non-Compliance  
Violations may result in:
- **Employees**: Disciplinary action up to and including **termination**  
- **Contractors/Vendors**: Immediate **termination of contract or assignment**  
- **Applications**: Must be **remediated within 90 days** of violation discovery

---

## 6. Related Standards, Policies and Processes

- **[Password Policy](#)** *(Link to your internal policy)*

---

## 7. Definitions and Terms

| Term | Definition (per [SANS Glossary](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/)) |
|------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **Credentials** | Data (e.g., username/password, certificate) used to verify identity. |
| **Executing Body** | The main runtime logic of a program that performs business functions. |
| **Hash Function** | A mathematical function that maps data to a fixed-size value; used for integrity and indexing. |
| **LDAP** | Lightweight Directory Access Protocol – a standard for accessing directory services like user authentication. |
| **Module** | A self-contained component of a software system, often reusable. |

> 🔗 Full definitions: [SANS Glossary of Terms](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/)

---

## 3. Scope

This policy defines appropriate **dial-in access** and its use by **authorized personnel**, including employees and approved third parties (e.g., vendors, customers).

---

## 4. Policy

- `<Company Name>` **employees** and **authorized third parties** may use dial-in connections to access the corporate network—**only when necessary** and under strict controls.
- **Dial-in access must use one-time password (OTP) authentication** or equivalent strong authentication (e.g., token-based MFA).
- Employees with dial-in privileges are **personally responsible** for ensuring that:
  - Non-employees **do not gain access** through their connection
  - The dial-in session is treated as a **direct extension** of the corporate network
  - All reasonable measures are taken to protect `<Company Name>`’s information assets

### Prohibited Connection Methods
- ❌ **Analog phones**  
- ❌ **Non-GSM digital cellular phones**  
  > *Reason*: These signals can be easily **scanned, intercepted, or hijacked** by unauthorized individuals.

- ✅ **Only GSM-standard digital cellular phones** are considered sufficiently secure for dial-in access (though even this is outdated by modern standards).

> 🔗 For current guidance on wireless access, refer to your organization’s **[Wireless Communications Policy](#6-related-standards-policies-and-processes)**.

### Account Management
- Dial-in accounts are **“as-needed”** accounts.
- Accounts are **monitored for usage**.
- If a dial-in account is **inactive for 6 months**, it will be **automatically disabled**.
- To regain access after expiration, the user must **submit a new request** through the standard provisioning process.

---

# Digital Signature Acceptance Policy

> **Free Use Disclaimer**: This policy was created by or for the SANS Institute for the Internet community. All or parts of this policy can be freely used for your organization. There is no prior approval required. If you would like to contribute a new policy or updated version of this policy, please send email to [policy-resources@sans.org](mailto:policy-resources@sans.org).  
> **Last Update Status**: Updated June 2014  
> © SANS Institute 2014 – All Rights Reserved

---

## 1. Overview

See [Purpose](#2-purpose).

---

## 2. Purpose

The purpose of this policy is to provide clear guidance on when **digital signatures** are considered an accepted means of validating the identity of a signer in `<Company Name>` electronic documents and correspondence—and thus a valid substitute for traditional “wet” (handwritten) signatures **within the organization**.

As internal communication has become primarily electronic, this policy aims to **reduce confusion** and **establish trust** in digitally signed content.

> **Note**: Replace `<Company Name>` with your actual organization name when implementing.

---

## 3. Scope

This policy applies to:

- All `<Company Name>` **employees**, **contractors**, and **agents**  
- Any individual conducting `<Company Name>` business using a **company-provided digital key pair**

> ⚠️ **Limitation**: This policy **only covers intra-organization** digitally signed documents and correspondence. It **does not apply** to electronic materials sent to or received from **external parties** (e.g., customers, vendors, government agencies).

---

## 4. Policy

- A **digital signature** is an **acceptable substitute** for a wet signature on any internal `<Company Name>` document or message—**except** for those explicitly excluded by the **Chief Financial Officer (CFO)**.
- The CFO’s office maintains a current list of **excluded document types** on the organization’s intranet:  
  [`<CFO’s Office URL>`](<CFO’s Office URL>)
- **Digital signatures must be tied to individuals only**.  
  ❌ Signatures associated with **roles**, **titles**, or **positions** (e.g., “CFO” or “HR Director”) are **not valid**.

---

### 4.1 Responsibilities

Digital signature acceptance requires **active participation** from both the **signer** and the **recipient**.

---

### 4.2 Signer Responsibilities

- **4.2.1** Obtain a signing key pair from the **`<Company Name>` Identity Management Group**.  
  - Keys must be generated via `<Company Name>`’s **Public Key Infrastructure (PKI)**  
  - The public key must be signed by `<Company Name>`’s **Certificate Authority (CA)**: **`<CA Name>`**

- **4.2.2** Use only **IT-approved software** to apply digital signatures.

- **4.2.3** **Protect the private key** at all times and keep it **confidential**.

- **4.2.4** Immediately report **suspected compromise** (e.g., theft, exposure) of the private key to the **Identity Management Group** for **revocation**.

---

### 4.3 Recipient Responsibilities

- **4.3.1** Use only **IT-approved software** to view signed documents.

- **4.3.2** **Verify** that the signer’s public key was issued and signed by `<Company Name>`’s CA (**`<CA Name>`**) by inspecting certificate details in the viewing software.

- **4.3.3** **Do not trust** the document if the digital signature appears **invalid, expired, or untrusted**.

- **4.3.4** Report any suspected **abuse or forgery** of digital signatures to the **Identity Management Group**.

> 🔗 **Key Terms** (from [SANS Glossary](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/)):  
> - [Digital Signature](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/#digital-signature): *A hash of a message that uniquely identifies the sender and proves message integrity.*  
> - [Certificate-Based Authentication](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/#certificate-based-authentication): *Use of SSL and certificates to authenticate and encrypt traffic.*

---

## 5. Policy Compliance

### 5.1 Compliance Measurement  
The Infosec team will verify compliance through:
- System and PKI audit logs  
- Internal/external audits  
- User feedback and incident reports

### 5.2 Exceptions  
All exceptions require **prior written approval** from the Infosec team.

### 5.3 Non-Compliance  
Violations may result in:
- **Disciplinary action**, up to and including **termination of employment**  
- **Revocation** of digital signing privileges

---

## 6. Related Standards, Policies and Processes

- **Internal PKI Policy**  
- **Password & Key Management Policy**  
- **Acceptable Use Policy**

> *(Add links to your organization’s internal policies as applicable.)*

---

## 7. References

> ⚖️ **Legal Note**: These references were used as guidance only. Consult your organization’s **legal counsel** to ensure compliance with applicable **federal, state, or local laws** (e.g., ESIGN Act, UETA).

- [American Bar Association (ABA) Digital Signature Guidelines](http://www.abanet.org/scitech/ec/isc/dsgfree.html)  
- [Minnesota State Agency Digital Signature Implementation](http://mn.gov/oet/policies-and-standards/business/policy/pages/standard_digital_signature.jsp)  
- [Minnesota Electronic Authentication Act (§325K)](https://www.revisor.leg.state.mn.us/statutes/?id=325K&view=chapter)  
- [City of Albuquerque Digital Signature Policy](http://mesa.cabq.gov/policy.nsf/WebApprovedX/4D4D4667D0A7953A87256E7B004F6720?OpenDocument)  
- [West Virginia Code §39A-3-2](http://law.justia.com/westvirginia/codes/39a/wvc39a-3-2.html)

---

## 8. Definitions and Terms

While no definitions were listed in the original policy, the following terms are central to this document:

| Term | Definition (per SANS Glossary) |
|------|-------------------------------|
| **Digital Signature** | A hash of a message that uniquely identifies the sender and proves the message hasn’t changed since transmission. |
| **Public Key Infrastructure (PKI)** | A framework of policies, procedures, and technologies that binds public keys with identities via digital certificates. |
| **Certificate Authority (CA)** | A trusted entity that issues and manages digital certificates. |

> Full definitions: [SANS Glossary of Terms](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/)

---

# DMZ Lab Security Policy

> **Free Use Disclaimer**: This policy was created by or for the SANS Institute for the Internet community. All or parts of this policy can be freely used for your organization. There is no prior approval required. If you would like to contribute a new policy or updated version of this policy, please send email to [policy-resources@sans.org](mailto:policy-resources@sans.org).  
> **Status**: **Retired** (Last Updated: July 2014)  
> © SANS Institute 2014 – All Rights Reserved

> ⚠️ **Note**: This policy has been **retired by SANS** and its content was merged into a broader **Lab Security Policy**. It is provided here for **historical reference** or for organizations maintaining legacy DMZ lab environments.

---

## 1. Overview

See [Purpose](#2-purpose).

---

## 2. Purpose

This policy establishes **information security requirements** for all networks and equipment deployed in `<Company Name>` labs located in the **De-Militarized Zone (DMZ)**.

Adherence to these requirements minimizes the risk of:
- Damage to `<Company Name>`’s **public image** due to unauthorized use of resources  
- Loss of **sensitive data**, **confidential information**, or **intellectual property**

> **Note**: Replace `<Company Name>` with your actual organization name when referencing or adapting.

---

## 3. Scope

This policy applies to:

- All **DMZ Labs** that are **Internet-facing** and located **outside** `<Company Name>`’s corporate Internet firewalls  
- Equipment including (but not limited to): **routers, switches, hosts, servers**  
- Labs at **primary ISP locations** and **remote sites**

> ❌ **Excluded**: Labs residing **inside** the corporate firewall are governed by the **[Internal Lab Security Policy](#)**.

All existing and future DMZ lab equipment must comply with referenced configuration standards.

---

## 4. Policy

### 4.1 Ownership and Responsibilities

1. **Business Justification**:  
   All new DMZ Labs require a **VP-level approved business justification**. The Infosec Team must retain this documentation.

2. **Lab Management**:  
   Lab-owning organizations must assign:
   - A **Lab Manager**  
   - A **Primary Point of Contact (POC)**  
   - A **Backup POC**  
   POC information must be kept current with the Infosec Team and enterprise management system (if applicable).  
   **24/7 availability** is required for emergencies.

3. **Change Control**:  
   Any change to connectivity, purpose, or creation of a new DMZ Lab must be requested through the **`<Company Name>` Network Support Organization** and **approved by the Infosec Team**.

4. **ISP & Firewall Management**:  
   - All ISP connections must be managed by the **Network Support Organization**  
   - A **firewall device** must be maintained between the DMZ Lab and the Internet

5. **Enforcement Authority**:  
   The **Infosec Team** and **Network Support Organization** may **interrupt lab connectivity** if a security risk is identified.

6. **Equipment Responsibility**:  
   The DMZ Lab provides and maintains all network devices **up to the Network Support Organization’s point of demarcation**.

7. **Asset Inventory**:  
   The Network Support Organization must record all **DMZ Lab IP address ranges** and **current POCs** in the corporate asset management system.

8. **Compliance Accountability**:  
   **Lab Managers** are ultimately responsible for ensuring compliance with this policy.

9. **Audit Access**:  
   The Infosec Team and Network Support Organization must be granted **immediate access** to equipment and logs upon request, per the **[Audit Policy](#6-related-standards-policies-and-processes)**.

10. **Account Management**:  
    - Individual accounts must be **deleted within 3 days** of access revocation  
    - Group account passwords must comply with the **[Password Policy](#)** and be **changed within 3 days** of membership changes

11. **Waivers**:  
    Non-compliance waiver requests will be reviewed **case-by-case** by the Infosec Team.

---

### 4.2 General Configuration Requirements

1. **No Production Dependencies**:  
   Production systems **must not depend** on DMZ Lab resources.

2. **Network Isolation**:  
   DMZ Labs **must not connect**—directly or wirelessly—to `<Company Name>`’s internal corporate networks.

3. **Physical Security**:  
   - DMZ Labs should be in a **physically separate room** from internal networks  
   - If not possible: equipment must be in a **locked rack** with **limited access**  
   - Lab Manager must maintain an **access log** of authorized personnel

4. **Policy Compliance**:  
   Lab Managers must comply with:
   - [Password Policy](#)
   - [Wireless Communications Policy](#)
   - [Lab Policy](#)

5. **Firewall Configuration**:  
   - Firewalls must follow the **least-access principle** aligned with business needs  
   - All firewall rules are **maintained by the Infosec Team**

6. **Single Access Point**:  
   The firewall is the **only permitted gateway** between the DMZ Lab and the Internet or internal networks.  
   **Bypassing the firewall is strictly prohibited**.

7. **Firewall Change Control**:  
   All firewall configurations and rule changes must be **reviewed and approved** by the Infosec Team. Additional security measures may be mandated.

8. **Inbound Traffic**:  
   Traffic from DMZ Labs to internal networks (including VPN) is governed by the **[Remote Access Policy](#)**.

9. **Network Device Standards**:  
   Routers and switches **not used for testing/training** must conform to `<Company Name>`’s **DMZ Router and Switch Standardization Documents**.

10. **Host Hardening**:  
    All hosts running Internet services must be configured per `<Company Name>`’s **Secure Host Installation Standards**.  
    > 🔗 *[Link to your internal secure configuration standards]*

11. **Patch Management**:  
    - **Current security patches/hotfixes** must be applied to all Internet-facing applications  
    - Administrative owners must have **processes to monitor vendor advisories**

12. **Service Minimization**:  
    All **unnecessary services and applications** must be **disabled**.

13. **Data Restrictions**:  
    **`<Company Name>` Confidential Information** is **prohibited** on equipment in labs with **non-employee physical access** (e.g., training labs), per the **[Data Classification and Protection Policy](#)**.

14. **Remote Administration**:  
    Must use **secure channels only**, such as:
    - **SSH**  
    - **IPsec**  
    - **Out-of-band console access** (independent of the DMZ network)

---

## 5. Policy Compliance

### 5.1 Compliance Measurement  
The Infosec Team will verify compliance through:
- Periodic walkthroughs  
- Video monitoring (where applicable)  
- Business tool reports  
- Internal and external audits  
- Stakeholder feedback

### 5.2 Exceptions  
All exceptions require **prior written approval** from the Infosec Team.

### 5.3 Non-Compliance  
Violations may result in:
- **Disciplinary action**, up to and including **termination of employment**

---

## 6. Related Standards, Policies and Processes

- [Audit Policy](#)  
- [Data Classification and Protection Policy](#)  
- [Lab Policy](#)  
- [Password Policy](#)  
- [Wireless Communications Policy](#)

> *(Replace with links to your organization’s internal policies.)*

---

## 7. Definitions and Terms

The following terms are defined in the **[SANS Glossary of Terms](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/)**:

| Term | Definition |
|------|-----------|
| **[De-militarized Zone (DMZ)](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/#demilitarized-zone-dmz)** | A subnetwork between an internal network and the Internet that hosts public-facing services with controlled access. |
| **[Firewall](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/#firewall)** | A system that enforces access control between networks based on predefined security rules. |
| **[Least Access Principle](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/#least-privilege)** | Granting users only the minimum access necessary to perform their duties. |
| **[Internet Services](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/#internet-service)** | Applications or protocols (e.g., HTTP, FTP, DNS) accessible over the public Internet. |
| **[Lab](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/#lab)** | A controlled environment for testing, development, or training. |

> 🔗 Full glossary: [SANS Security Glossary](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/)

# Email Policy

> **Free Use Disclaimer**: This policy was created by or for the SANS Institute for the Internet community. All or parts of this policy can be freely used for your organization. There is no prior approval required. If you would like to contribute a new policy or updated version of this policy, please send email to [policy-resources@sans.org](mailto:policy-resources@sans.org).  
> **Last Update Status**: Updated December 2013  
> © SANS Institute 2013 – All Rights Reserved

---

## 1. Overview

Electronic email is pervasively used across nearly all industries and often serves as the **primary method of communication and awareness** within an organization. However, misuse of email can introduce significant **legal, privacy, and security risks**. Therefore, it is essential that all users understand the **appropriate use** of electronic communications.

---

## 2. Purpose

The purpose of this policy is to:

- Ensure the **proper use** of the `<Company Name>` email system  
- Clearly define what constitutes **acceptable and unacceptable use**  
- Establish **minimum requirements** for email usage on the `<Company Name>` network

> **Note**: Replace `<Company Name>` with your actual organization name when implementing.

---

## 3. Scope

This policy applies to:

- All **employees**, **vendors**, **contractors**, and **agents** acting on behalf of `<Company Name>`  
- Any email **sent from a `<Company Name>` email address**, regardless of device or location

---

## 4. Policy

### 4.1 Ethical and Legal Compliance  
All email use must align with:
- `<Company Name>` policies and procedures  
- Standards of **ethical conduct**, **safety**, and **proper business practices**  
- All **applicable local, state, and federal laws**

### 4.2 Primary Use for Business  
- `<Company Name>` email accounts **must be used primarily for business purposes**  
- **Limited personal use** is permitted (e.g., brief personal messages)  
- ❌ **Non-`<Company Name>` commercial activities are strictly prohibited**

### 4.3 Data Protection  
All data in email messages or attachments must be protected in accordance with the **[Data Protection Standard](#6-related-standards-policies-and-processes)**.

### 4.4 Email as a Business Record  
- Email **should only be retained** if it qualifies as a **`<Company Name>` business record**  
- A business record exists when there is a **legitimate and ongoing business reason** to preserve the information

### 4.5 Record Retention  
Email identified as a business record **must be retained** per the **`<Company Name>` Record Retention Schedule**.

### 4.6 Prohibited Content  
The email system **must not be used** to create or distribute:
- Disruptive or offensive messages  
- Comments related to **race, gender, age, disability, sexual orientation, religion, political beliefs, national origin**, etc.  
- Pornographic or harassing content  

> 🛑 Employees who receive such messages from a `<Company Name>` account must **report immediately to their supervisor**.

### 4.7 Forwarding Restrictions  
- ❌ **Automatic forwarding** of `<Company Name>` email to third-party systems (e.g., Gmail, Yahoo) is **prohibited**  
- Manual forwarding of individual messages is allowed **only if** they **do not contain confidential or higher-classified data**

### 4.8 Third-Party Email Systems  
Users are **prohibited** from using external email services (e.g., Google, Yahoo, Hotmail) to:
- Conduct `<Company Name>` business  
- Create or memorialize **binding transactions**  
- Store or retain company email  

> ✅ All official communications must use **`<Company Name>`-approved systems and documentation**.

### 4.9 Personal Use Guidelines  
- **Reasonable personal use** of email is acceptable  
- Personal messages **must be stored in a separate folder** from work-related email  
- ❌ **Chain letters, jokes, hoaxes, or mass forwards** from a `<Company Name>` account are **prohibited**

### 4.10 No Expectation of Privacy  
Employees **have no expectation of privacy** in any content:
- Sent  
- Received  
- Stored  
on the `<Company Name>` email system.

### 4.11 Monitoring  
- `<Company Name>` **may monitor** email messages **without prior notice**  
- Monitoring is **not guaranteed**—the company is **not obligated** to review all messages

---

## 5. Policy Compliance

### 5.1 Compliance Measurement  
The Infosec team will verify compliance through:
- Periodic walkthroughs  
- Business tool reports (e.g., DLP, email logs)  
- Internal and external audits  
- User and manager feedback

### 5.2 Exceptions  
All exceptions require **prior written approval** from the Infosec team.

### 5.3 Non-Compliance  
Violations may result in:
- **Disciplinary action**, up to and including **termination of employment**  
- **Revocation** of email and system access privileges

---

- **[Record Retention Policy](#)**  
- **[Acceptable Use Policy](#)**  
- **[Privacy Policy](#)**

> *(Link to your organization’s internal policies as applicable.)*

|------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **Email** | Electronic mail; a method of exchanging digital messages over a network. |
| **Business Record** | Information created or received in the course of official business that must be retained for legal, fiscal, or operational reasons. |
| **Confidential Data** | Information that must be protected from unauthorized access due to sensitivity (e.g., PII, financial data). |

This policy is **secondary** to `<Company Name>`’s:
- **Freedom of Information Policy**  
- **Business Record Keeping Policy**

> 📌 **Rule**: Any email falling under the **Business Record Keeping Policy** must be treated as a **business record**, regardless of category below.

All `<Company Name>` email is classified into **four retention categories**:

| Category | Retention Period |
|--------|------------------|
| **Administrative Correspondence** | 4 years |
| **Fiscal Correspondence** | 4 years |
| **General Correspondence** | 1 year |
| **Ephemeral Correspondence** | Retain until read, then destroy |

---

## 4. Policy

### 4.1 Administrative Correspondence
Includes (but not limited to):
- Clarifications of company policy (e.g., holidays, dress code, time cards)  
- Workplace behavior guidelines  
- Legal matters (e.g., intellectual property violations)  
- All emails labeled **“Management Only”**

✅ **Retention Method**:  
- **CC** the dedicated mailbox: [`admin@<Company Name>`](mailto:admin@<Company Name>)  
- The **IT Department** will manage retention automatically

### 4.2 Fiscal Correspondence
Includes all information related to **revenue and expenses**.

✅ **Retention Method**:  
- **CC** the dedicated mailbox: [`fiscal@<Company Name>`](mailto:fiscal@<Company Name>)  
- The **IT Department** will manage retention automatically

### 4.3 General Correspondence
Covers:
- Customer interactions  
- Operational business decisions

👤 **Retention Responsibility**:  
- **Individual employees** are responsible for retaining and disposing of these emails per the 1-year rule.

### 4.4 Ephemeral Correspondence
The **largest category**, including:
- Personal emails  
- Requests for recommendations or reviews  
- Product development discussions  
- Status updates and routine notifications

🗑️ **Action**:  
- Retain **only until read or acted upon**, then **delete immediately**

### 4.5 Instant Messenger (IM) Correspondence
- **General IM logs** may be saved using the IM client’s logging feature or copied to a file  
- **Administrative or Fiscal IM conversations** must be:
  1. Copied into an **email message**  
  2. Sent to the appropriate retention mailbox (`admin@...` or `fiscal@...`)

✅ **Approved IM Client**:  
- **Jabber Secure IM Client** is the **only approved** IM application on `<Company Name>` devices

### 4.6 Encrypted Communications
- Store encrypted messages in a manner consistent with the **[Information Sensitivity Policy](#)**  
- **Generally**, sensitive information should be stored in **decrypted format** only when necessary for business use and with proper access controls

### 4.7 Recovering Deleted Email via Backup Media
- Email server backups are retained on **quarterly offsite tapes**  
- **No effort** will be made to purge specific emails from offsite backup media  
- Recovery from backups is **not guaranteed** and should not be relied upon for compliance

### 4.8 General Standards

#### Approved Email Systems
- Only **IT-supported email platforms** are approved (e.g., Microsoft Outlook, Google Workspace)  
- Business need for alternate systems must be reviewed by IT

#### Approved Encryption
- **DES** and **PGP** are approved encryption methods  
- PGP use requires a **company license** — contact IT to request

#### Approved Instant Messenger
- **Jabber Secure IM Client** only

#### Individual Access Controls
- Use OS-level protections:
  - **Unix/Linux**: `chmod` for file permissions  
  - **Windows/macOS**: Password-protected screensavers, encrypted volumes (e.g., BitLocker, FileVault)

#### Insecure Internet Links
- Any network link **not fully controlled** by `<Company Name>` is considered insecure  
- Treat data transmitted over such links as **exposed**

#### Encryption Compliance
- Encrypt `<Company Name>` **Sensitive Information** per the **[Acceptable Encryption Policy](#6-related-standards-policies-and-processes)**  
- Consult **Legal** and **management** regarding **international cryptography export controls**

---
