# Employee Internet Use Monitoring and Filtering Policy

> **Free Use Disclaimer**: This policy was created by or for the SANS Institute for the Internet community. All or parts of this policy can be freely used for your organization. There is no prior approval required. If you would like to contribute a new policy or updated version of this policy, please send email to [policy-resources@sans.org](mailto:policy-resources@sans.org).  
> **Status**: **Retired** (Last Updated: July 2014)  
> © SANS Institute 2014 – All Rights Reserved

> ⚠️ **Note**: This policy has been **retired by SANS** but provides a solid foundation for modern web use policies. Consider integrating its principles into a current **Acceptable Use Policy** or **Secure Web Gateway Standard**.

---

## 1. Overview

See [Purpose](#2-purpose).

---

## 2. Purpose

This policy defines standards for systems that **monitor and limit web use** from any host within the `<Company Name>` network. These standards are designed to:

- Ensure employees use the Internet in a **safe and responsible** manner  
- Enable **monitoring and forensic research** of web activity during security incidents

> **Note**: Replace `<Company Name>` with your actual organization name when implementing.

---

## 3. Scope

This policy applies to:

- All **employees**, **contractors**, **vendors**, and **agents**  
- Any **company-owned or personally-owned device** connected to the `<Company Name>` network

It covers **all user-initiated Internet communications**, including:
- Web browsing  
- Instant messaging  
- File transfer and sharing  
- Other standard or proprietary protocols

> ❌ **Excluded**:  
> - Server-to-server traffic (e.g., SMTP, automated backups, database syncs)  
> - System-initiated or scheduled data transfers

---

## 4. Policy

### 4.1 Web Site Monitoring

The **Information Technology (IT) Department** shall monitor all Internet use from devices on the corporate network. The monitoring system **must record**:

- Source IP address  
- Date and time  
- Protocol used  
- Destination site or server  

✅ **Where technically feasible**, the system **should also log** the **User ID** associated with the session.

📁 **Retention**: Internet use records must be **preserved for 180 days**.

---

### 4.2 Access to Monitoring Reports

| Audience | Access Level |
|--------|--------------|
| **General Employees** | May request **anonymized, aggregated trend reports** from IT |
| **CSIRT (Computer Security Incident Response Team)** | Full access to **all raw data and user-identified reports** for incident response |
| **HR or Management** | May access **user-specific reports** only with a **written or email request** from a **Human Resources representative** |

> 🔒 All access to identifiable data must comply with privacy and data handling policies.

---

### 4.3 Internet Use Filtering System

The IT Department shall **block access** to websites and protocols deemed **inappropriate** for the corporate environment. The following categories **must be blocked**:

- Adult / Sexually Explicit Material  
- Advertisements & Pop-Ups  
- Chat and Instant Messaging  
- Gambling  
- Hacking  
- Illegal Drugs  
- Intimate Apparel and Swimwear  
- Peer-to-Peer (P2P) File Sharing  
- Personals and Dating  
- Social Network Services  
- SPAM, Phishing, and Fraud  
- Spyware  
- Tasteless and Offensive Content  
- Violence, Intolerance, and Hate  
- Web-Based Email (e.g., Gmail, Yahoo Mail)

> 🔗 **Definitions** (from [SANS Glossary](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/)):  
> - [Peer-to-Peer File Sharing](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/#peer-to-peer-file-sharing)  
> - [Social Networking Services](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/#social-networking)  
> - [SPAM](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/#spam)  
> - [Phishing](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/#phishing)  
> - [Hacking](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/#hacking)

---

### 4.4 Filtering Rule Changes

- The **IT Department** will **periodically review** and recommend updates to filtering rules.  
- **Human Resources (HR)** will review these recommendations and **approve or deny** changes.  
- Approved changes will be **documented in this policy**.

---

### 4.5 Filtering Exceptions

#### Misclassified Sites
- Employees may request unblocking of **mis-categorized sites** via the **IT Help Desk**.  
- IT will review and **unblock if appropriate**.

#### Business-Justified Access
- If a **correctly categorized** site is needed for **legitimate business purposes**:
  1. Employee submits request to **HR representative**  
  2. HR approves and forwards request **in writing or email** to IT  
  3. IT grants **user-specific, time-bound access**  
  4. All exceptions are **logged and reported** upon request

---

## 5. Policy Compliance

### 5.1 Compliance Measurement  
The Infosec team will verify compliance through:
- System logs and monitoring reports  
- Internal/external audits  
- Periodic reviews and user feedback

### 5.2 Exceptions  
All exceptions require **prior approval** from the Infosec team **and** HR (for filtering overrides).

### 5.3 Non-Compliance  
Violations may result in:
- **Disciplinary action**, up to and including **termination of employment**  
- **Revocation** of network or system access

---

- **[Data Privacy Policy](#)**  
- **[Incident Response Policy](#)**  
- **[Remote Work Policy](#)** *(if BYOD is allowed)*

The following terms are defined in the **[SANS Glossary of Terms](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/)**:

| Term | Definition |
|------|-----------|
| **Peer-to-Peer File Sharing** | Decentralized file exchange between users without a central server; often used for copyright infringement or malware distribution. |
| **Social Networking Services** | Online platforms (e.g., Facebook, LinkedIn) enabling user interaction and content sharing. |
| **SPAM** | Unsolicited bulk electronic messages, often commercial or malicious. |
| **Phishing** | Fraudulent attempt to obtain sensitive information by masquerading as a trustworthy entity. |
| **Hacking** | Gaining unauthorized access to data or systems, often with malicious intent. |

content:
# End User Encryption Key Protection Policy

> **Free Use Disclaimer**: This policy was created by or for the SANS Institute for the Internet community. All or parts of this policy can be freely used for your organization. There is no prior approval required. If you would like to contribute a new policy or updated version of this policy, please send email to [policy-resources@sans.org](mailto:policy-resources@sans.org).  
> **Last Update Status**: Updated June 2014  
> © SANS Institute 2014 – All Rights Reserved

---

## 1. Overview

Improper **encryption key management** can lead to the compromise of **private keys** used to protect sensitive data—ultimately resulting in **data disclosure**. While users may understand the importance of encrypting documents and communications, they may not be familiar with **minimum standards for protecting encryption keys**.

This policy ensures that end users apply appropriate safeguards to prevent unauthorized access, loss, or misuse of cryptographic keys.

> **Note**: Replace `<Company Name>` with your actual organization name when implementing.

---

## 2. Purpose

This policy defines requirements for protecting **encryption keys under end-user control** to prevent:
- Unauthorized disclosure  
- Fraudulent use  

Protection methods include **operational and technical controls**, such as:
- Secure key backup procedures  
- Encryption of keys under stronger keys  
- Use of **tamper-resistant hardware** (e.g., smart cards)

---

## 3. Scope

This policy applies to:

- Any **encryption key** that is:
  - Issued by `<Company Name>`  
  - Used for `<Company Name>` business  
  - Used to protect `<Company Name>`-owned data  

> ✅ **Excluded**: **Public keys** contained in digital certificates are **not covered** by this policy.

It also applies to **any individual responsible** for managing such keys (employees, contractors, agents).

---

## 4. Policy

All covered encryption keys **must be protected** to prevent unauthorized disclosure and misuse.

### 4.1 Secret Key (Symmetric) Encryption Keys

- Symmetric keys **must be protected during distribution**.
- During transit, they **must be encrypted** using:
  - A **stronger algorithm** than the one they protect  
  - The **longest key length** authorized in the **[Acceptable Encryption Policy](#6-related-standards-policies-and-processes)**
- If the key is for the **strongest allowed algorithm**, it **must be split**:
  - Each portion encrypted with a **different key** (using max-length keys)  
  - Each portion sent via a **different transmission mechanism**
- **At rest**, symmetric keys must be protected with **security measures at least as strong** as those used during distribution.

> 🔗 **Term**: [Symmetric cryptography](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/#symmetric-cryptography) — *Uses a single shared secret key for both encryption and decryption.*

---

### 4.2 Public Key (Asymmetric) Encryption Keys

Asymmetric cryptography uses **public-private key pairs**:
- **Public key**: Shared via digital certificate (exempt from this policy)
- **Private key**: Must remain **exclusively with the end user**

#### 4.2.1 `<Company Name>` Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) Keys

- Key pairs are **generated on tamper-resistant smart cards** issued to users.
- **Identity certificate private keys** (used for **digital signatures**) **never leave the smart card**.
  - ❌ **No escrow** is performed for these keys.
- **Encryption certificate private keys** (used for email/document encryption) **must be escrowed** per company policy.
- Access to private keys on the smart card requires a **PIN known only to the user**.
- Smart card software **must prompt for PIN** before any private key operation.

> 🔗 **Terms**:  
> - [Digital signature](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/#digital-signature)  
> - [Public key cryptography](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/#public-key-cryptography)

#### 4.2.2 Other Public Key Encryption Keys

- Keys generated in **software** (e.g., on a hard drive or USB token) must:
  - Have **at least one secure backup**  
  - Include an **escrow copy** of **encryption private keys** delivered to the **local Infosec representative**
- ❌ **Identity certificate private keys must not be escrowed**
- All backups and escrow copies **must be password-protected** per the **[Password Policy](#)**
- Escrowed keys are stored per the **[Certificate Practice Statement Policy](#)**

#### 4.2.2.1 Commercial or External PKI Keys

- When using external CAs (e.g., DigiCert, Sectigo), browsers often generate key pairs locally.
- Private keys reside in the **browser certificate store**, protected **only by a password**.
- Browsers **must be configured** to require the certificate store password **every time a private key is accessed**.

#### 4.2.2.2 PGP Key Pairs

- PGP keys may be stored in **keyring files** (on disk) or on **hardware tokens** (e.g., USB, smart card).
- **Hardware token storage is preferred** due to stronger physical protection.
- PGP **must be configured** to require the **passphrase for every private key use**.

> 🔗 **Term**: [Key escrow](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/#key-escrow) — *A method of storing private keys with a trusted third party for recovery.*

---

### 4.3 Hardware Token Storage

- Hardware tokens (smart cards, USB tokens, etc.) are **sensitive company equipment** per the **[Physical Security Policy](#)**.
- When **outside company offices**, tokens must be secured accordingly.
- Tokens **must not remain connected** to a computer when **not in use**.
- While **traveling**, tokens **must not be stored in the same bag or container** as the user’s computer.

---

### 4.4 PINs, Passwords, and Passphrases

- All credentials used to protect encryption keys **must comply** with the **[Password Policy](#)**:
  - Minimum length  
  - Complexity requirements  
  - Rotation rules

---

### 4.5 Loss and Theft

- **Immediate reporting** is required for:
  - Loss  
  - Theft  
  - Suspected unauthorized disclosure  
  of any covered encryption key
- Report to the **Infosec Team**
- Infosec will direct actions such as:
  - Certificate revocation  
  - Key pair retirement  
  - Reissuance

---

## 5. Policy Compliance

### 5.1 Compliance Measurement  
The Infosec team will verify compliance through:
- Periodic walkthroughs  
- System and token audits  
- Internal/external audits  
- User and manager feedback

### 5.2 Exceptions  
All exceptions require **prior written approval** from the Infosec Team.

### 5.3 Non-Compliance  
Violations may result in:
- **Disciplinary action**, up to and including **termination of employment**

---

## 6. Related Standards, Policies and Processes

- **[Acceptable Encryption Policy](#)**  
- **[Certificate Practice Statement Policy](#)**  
- **[Password Policy](#)**  
- **[Physical Security Policy](#)**

> *(Link to your organization’s internal policies as applicable.)*

---

## 7. Definitions and Terms

The following terms are defined in the **[SANS Glossary of Terms](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/)**:

| Term | Definition |
|------|-----------|
| **[Certificate Authority (CA)](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/#certificate-authority-ca)** | An entity that issues digital certificates. |
| **[Digital Certificate](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/#digital-certificate)** | An electronic document binding a public key to an identity. |
| **[Digital Signature](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/#digital-signature)** | A hash proving message integrity and sender identity. |
| **[Key Escrow](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/#key-escrow)** | Secure storage of private keys with a trusted party. |
| **[Plaintext](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/#plaintext)** | Unencrypted, readable data. |
| **[Public Key Cryptography](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/#public-key-cryptography)** | Asymmetric encryption using public/private key pairs. |
| **[Public Key Pairs](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/#public-key-pairs)** | A mathematically linked public and private key. |
| **[Symmetric Cryptography](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/#symmetric-cryptography)** | Encryption using a single shared secret key. |

---

| Date       | Responsible        | Summary of Change               |
|------------|--------------------|----------------------------------|
| June 2014  | SANS Policy Team   | Updated and converted to new format. |

---

> **End of Policy**

# Ethics Policy

> **Free Use Disclaimer**: This policy was created by or for the SANS Institute for the Internet community. All or parts of this policy can be freely used for your organization. There is no prior approval required. If you would like to contribute a new policy or updated version of this policy, please send email to [policy-resources@sans.org](mailto:policy-resources@sans.org).  
> **Last Update Status**: Updated June 2014  
> © SANS Institute 2014 – All Rights Reserved

---

## 1. Overview

`<Company Name>` is committed to protecting its **employees, partners, vendors, and the company itself** from illegal or damaging actions—whether intentional or unintentional. By addressing issues proactively and exercising sound judgment, `<Company Name>` distinguishes itself through **integrity and responsibility**.

`<Company Name>` **will not tolerate wrongdoing or impropriety** under any circumstances. Should a breach of ethical conduct occur, the company will act **swiftly and decisively** to correct the issue.

> **Note**: Replace `<Company Name>` with your actual organization name when implementing.

---

## 2. Purpose

This policy establishes a culture of **openness, trust, fairness, and accountability**. It reinforces the expectation that all employees and stakeholders will be treated with **respect and ethical consideration**.

The policy serves as a guide for **business behavior** and ensures that ethical conduct is embedded in daily operations. **Ethics is a shared responsibility**—every `<Company Name>` employee plays a vital role in upholding these standards.

All personnel are expected to **review and understand** the ethics guidelines that follow.

---

## 3. Scope

This policy applies to:
- All **employees** (full-time, part-time, temporary)  
- **Contractors**, **consultants**, and **third-party workers**  
- Any individual performing work on behalf of `<Company Name>`

---

## 4. Policy

### 4.1 Executive Commitment to Ethics

1. **Lead by Example**:  
   Senior leaders and executives must model **honesty, integrity, and ethical decision-making** in all business practices.

2. **Open-Door Policy**:  
   Executives must maintain an **open-door policy**, welcoming employee feedback, concerns, and suggestions to foster transparency and early issue detection.

3. **Conflict of Interest Disclosure**:  
   Executives must **promptly disclose** any actual or potential conflicts of interest related to their role at `<Company Name>`.

---

### 4.2 Employee Commitment to Ethics

1. **Fair Treatment & Respect**:  
   Employees will treat all individuals with **fairness, dignity, and mutual respect**, and avoid any behavior that creates the **appearance of impropriety**.

2. **Active Participation**:  
   Every employee is expected to apply **diligence and integrity** in upholding ethical values.

3. **Conflict of Interest Disclosure**:  
   Employees must disclose any **personal, financial, or professional conflicts** that could influence their objectivity or loyalty to `<Company Name>`.

4. **Customer & Vendor Commitment**:  
   Employees will enhance stakeholder satisfaction by delivering **quality products** and **timely, professional responses**.

5. **Ethical Decision-Making Checklist**:  
   When in doubt, employees should ask themselves:
   - Is the behavior **legal**?  
   - Does it comply with all **`<Company Name>` policies**?  
   - Does it reflect our **core values and culture**?  
   - Could it **harm stakeholders** (customers, employees, partners)?  
   - Would I be **personally embarrassed** if this appeared in the news?  
   - What if **every employee** did this—would it still be acceptable?

---

### 4.3 Company Awareness

1. **Recognition of Ethical Behavior**:  
   `<Company Name>` will **recognize and reward** employees who promote ethical conduct in their communications and actions.

2. **Culture of Trust**:  
   The company fosters a **trustworthy, honest, and transparent** environment to reinforce its ethical vision.

---

### 4.4 Maintaining Ethical Practices

1. **Tone from the Top**:  
   Ethical leadership begins with executives and cascades through all levels—**managers, directors, and individual contributors** must consistently model ethical behavior.

2. **Open Dialogue**:  
   Employees are encouraged to engage in **honest conversations**, provide **constructive feedback**, and treat others with **fairness and objectivity**.

3. **Ethics Oversight**:  
   `<Company Name>` has established a **Best Practice Disclosure Committee** to:
   - Ensure the Ethics Policy is communicated company-wide  
   - Address concerns or questions about ethical conduct

4. **Annual Recertification**:  
   All employees are **required to recertify compliance** with this Ethics Policy **annually**.

---

### 4.5 Unethical Behavior

`<Company Name>` strictly prohibits:

- Any **appearance or intent** of unethical or compromising conduct  
- **Harassment, discrimination**, or hostile work environments  
- **Unauthorized use or disclosure** of company assets, including:
  - Trade secrets  
  - Marketing, operational, or financial data  
  - Source code  
  - Personnel or technical information  
- **Personal use of corporate assets** or business relationships for **private gain**

The company will act **ethically, lawfully, and responsibly** at all times and will not permit impropriety under any circumstance.

---

## 5. Policy Compliance

### 5.1 Compliance Measurement  
The **Employee Resource Team** (or HR/Compliance Department) will verify compliance through:
- Internal and external audits  
- Business tool reports (e.g., ethics hotline logs)  
- Employee feedback and surveys

### 5.2 Exceptions  
**None.** This policy allows **no exceptions**.

### 5.3 Non-Compliance  
Violations may result in:
- **Disciplinary action**, up to and including **termination of employment**  
- **Legal action**, where applicable

---

- **[Code of Conduct](#)**  
- **[Anti-Harassment Policy](#)**  
- **[Conflict of Interest Policy](#)**  
- **[Data Protection & Confidentiality Policy](#)**

> *(Link to your organization’s internal policies as applicable.)*

| **Due Care** | Ensuring a minimal level of protection in accordance with industry best practices. |
| **Due Diligence** | The requirement to develop and deploy protection plans and detection mechanisms for fraud or abuse. |

---

## 1. Overview

See [Purpose](#2-purpose).

---

## 2. Purpose

This policy defines the requirements for **third-party organizations** to securely connect to `<Company Name>` networks for the purpose of conducting authorized business.

> **Note**: Replace `<Company Name>` with your actual organization name when implementing.

---

## 3. Scope

This policy applies to **all connections** between third parties and `<Company Name>` that provide access to **non-public resources**, regardless of technology used:
- **VPN**
- **Frame Relay**
- **ISDN**
- **Private circuits**
- **Cloud-based secure tunnels**

> ❌ **Excluded**:  
> - Connections to **Internet Service Providers (ISPs)** for general Internet access  
> - Connectivity to the **Public Switched Telephone Network (PSTN)**

---

## 4. Policy

### 4.1 Pre-Requisites

#### 4.1.1 Security Review  
All new extranet connections must undergo a **security review** by the **Information Security (InfoSec) Department** to:
- Validate alignment with **business requirements**  
- Ensure adherence to the **principle of least access**

#### 4.1.2 Third Party Connection Agreement  
- A **signed Third Party Agreement** is required for every connection  
- Must be signed by:
  - **Vice President** of the `<Company Name>` Sponsoring Organization  
  - **Legally authorized representative** of the third party  
- Agreements must be **retained on file** by the relevant extranet team  
- For lab connections: stored with the **[Team Responsible for Lab Security]**

#### 4.1.3 Business Case  
- All **production extranet connections** require a **written business justification**  
  - Approved by a **Project Manager** in the extranet group  
- **Lab connections** require approval from the **[Team Responsible for Lab Security]**  
- Typically fulfilled as part of the Third Party Agreement process

#### 4.1.4 Point of Contact (POC)  
- The Sponsoring Organization must designate a **POC** responsible for:
  - Policy compliance  
  - Coordination with InfoSec and extranet teams  
- Any POC change must be **promptly communicated** to the extranet management group

---

### 4.2 Establishing Connectivity

- Sponsoring Organizations must submit a **new site request** to the **extranet group**  
- The extranet group will:
  - Engage **InfoSec** for security assessment  
  - For lab connections, engage the **[Lab Security Team]**  
- Full details of the proposed access must be provided upon request  
- All connectivity must follow the **least-access principle**  
- `<Company Name>` **will not rely** on the third party to protect its network or data

---

### 4.3 Modifying or Changing Connectivity

- All access changes require:
  - A **valid business justification**  
  - A **security review**  
- Changes must be implemented via the **corporate change management process**  
- The Sponsoring Organization must **notify InfoSec/extranet teams** of any material changes to original assumptions

---

### 4.4 Terminating Access

- When access is no longer needed, the **Sponsoring Organization** must notify the **extranet team** for deprovisioning  
- Termination may include:
  - Revoking permissions  
  - Disabling accounts  
  - Disconnecting circuits  

#### Annual Audit Requirement
- The **extranet team** and **lab security team** must conduct **annual audits** of all external connections to:
  - Confirm ongoing business need  
  - Verify access remains appropriate  
- **Deprecated or unused connections** will be **terminated immediately**

> 🛑 In the event of a **security incident** or discovery of an unused circuit, **InfoSec or the extranet team will notify the POC** before taking action, when feasible.

---

## 5. Policy Compliance

### 5.1 Compliance Measurement  
The Infosec team will verify compliance through:
- Access reviews and audit logs  
- Internal/external audits  
- Business tool reports (e.g., IAM, network monitoring)  
- Feedback from stakeholders

### 5.2 Exceptions  
All exceptions require **prior written approval** from the Infosec team.

### 5.3 Non-Compliance  
Violations may result in:
- **Disciplinary action**, up to and including **termination of employment**  
- **Immediate revocation** of third-party access

# Information Logging Standard

> **Free Use Disclaimer**: This policy was created by or for the SANS Institute for the Internet community. All or parts of this policy can be freely used for your organization. There is no prior approval required. If you would like to contribute a new policy or updated version of this policy, please send email to [policy-resources@sans.org](mailto:policy-resources@sans.org).  
> **Last Update Status**: Updated June 2014  
> © SANS Institute 2014 – All Rights Reserved

---

## 1. Overview

Logging from **critical systems, applications, and services** provides essential data for detecting anomalies, investigating incidents, and conducting **forensic analysis**. While logs may not be reviewed daily, their availability is **critical** for security, compliance, and operational integrity.

---

## 2. Purpose

This standard defines **minimum audit logging requirements** for information systems to ensure they:

- Generate meaningful, actionable logs  
- Integrate effectively with enterprise **log management** functions  

This language is designed to be incorporated into:
- Enterprise IT security policies  
- Procurement standards  
- RFP/RFQ templates  

> ✅ Ensures that **both in-house and vendor-procured systems** support necessary logging capabilities.

> **Note**: Replace `<Company Name>` with your actual organization name when implementing.

---

## 3. Scope

This standard applies to **all production systems** on the `<Company Name>` network, including:
- Servers  
- Applications  
- Network devices  
- Cloud workloads  
- Security appliances  

---

## 4. Standard

### 4.1 General Requirements

All systems that:
- Handle **confidential information**,  
- Accept **network connections**, or  
- Make **access control decisions** (authentication/authorization)  

**must record and retain audit logs** sufficient to answer the following **7 key questions**:

1. **What** activity was performed?  
2. **Who or what** performed it? (including source system/IP)  
3. **What** was the activity performed **on**? (target object)  
4. **When** was it performed?  
5. **What tool(s)** were used?  
6. **What was the outcome**? (success/failure/error)  
7. *(Implied)* **Why** was it allowed or denied?

---

### 4.2 Activities to Be Logged

Logs **must be generated** for the following events:

1. **Create, read, update, or delete** confidential information (including passwords)  
2. **Create, update, or delete** non-confidential data  
3. **Initiate** a network connection  
4. **Accept** a network connection  
5. **User authentication/authorization** (e.g., login, logout)  
6. **Grant, modify, or revoke access rights**, including:
   - Adding users/groups  
   - Changing privileges  
   - Modifying file/database permissions  
   - Updating firewall rules  
   - Password changes  
7. **System, network, or service configuration changes**, including:
   - Software installations/updates  
   - Patch deployment  
8. **Application process startup, shutdown, or restart**  
9. **Application failures or abnormal terminations**, especially due to:
   - Resource exhaustion (CPU, memory, disk, bandwidth)  
   - Service failures (e.g., DNS, DHCP)  
   - Hardware faults  
10. **Detection of suspicious/malicious activity** by:
    - IDS/IPS  
    - Anti-virus  
    - Anti-malware or EDR systems  

---

### 4.3 Required Log Elements

Each log entry **must contain or unambiguously infer** the following elements:

| Element | Examples |
|--------|--------|
| **1. Type of action** | `create`, `read`, `update`, `delete`, `accept-connection` |
| **2. Subsystem** | Process name, transaction ID, service name |
| **3. Subject identifiers** | Username, hostname, **IP address**, **MAC address** *(standardized for correlation)* |
| **4. Object identifiers** | Filename, database record ID, query parameters, IP/MAC *(standardized)* |
| **5. Before/after values** | For updates (if feasible) |
| **6. Timestamp** | With **timezone** (preferably UTC) |
| **7. Access decision** | `allowed` or `denied` |
| **8. Denial reason** | Error code, policy violation description |

> 🔍 **Note**: "Indirectly" means the value can be reliably derived from other logged data.

---

### 4.4 Formatting and Storage

Systems **must support log formatting and storage** that ensures:
- **Log integrity**  
- **Enterprise-level analysis and reporting**

✅ **Approved Logging Mechanisms Include**:

1. **Microsoft Windows Event Logs** → collected by a centralized log management system  
2. **Syslog / syslog-ng / syslog-reliable** → sent to a centralized log management system  
3. **ANSI-SQL database logs** → where the database itself complies with this standard  
4. **Open standards** such as:
   - **ArcSight CEF** (Common Event Format)  
   - **IDMEF** (Intrusion Detection Message Exchange Format)  
   - **Check Point OPSEC**  
   - **CEF, LEEF, or JSON-based structured logging**

> 📌 **Note**: The design of the enterprise log management system itself is **outside the scope** of this standard.

---

## 5. Policy Compliance

### 5.1 Compliance Measurement  
The Infosec team will verify compliance through:
- System configuration reviews  
- Log sample audits  
- Internal/external assessments  
- Procurement validation (for new systems)

### 5.2 Exceptions  
All exceptions require **prior written approval** from the Infosec team.

### 5.3 Non-Compliance  
Violations may result in:
- **Disciplinary action**, up to and including **termination of employment**  
- **Rejection of non-compliant systems** in procurement

---

## 6. Related Standards, Policies and Processes

- **[Incident Response Policy](#)**  
- **[Data Classification Policy](#)**  
- **[System Hardening Standards](#)**  
- **[Log Retention Policy](#)**

> *(Link to your organization’s internal policies as applicable.)*

---

## 7. Definitions and Terms

While no definitions were listed in the original document, the following terms are relevant:

| Term | Definition (per [SANS Glossary](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/)) |
|------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **Audit Log** | A chronological record of system activities used for compliance, forensics, and monitoring. |
| **Confidential Information** | Data that must be protected from unauthorized access (e.g., PII, financial records). |
| **Intrusion Detection System (IDS)** | A system that monitors network or system activities for malicious activities or policy violations. |

> 🔗 Full definitions: [SANS Glossary of Terms](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/)

---

---

# Internet Usage Policy

> **Free Use Disclaimer**: This policy was created by or for the SANS Institute for the Internet community. All or parts of this policy can be freely used for your organization. There is no prior approval required. If you would like to contribute a new policy or updated version of this policy, please send email to [policy-resources@sans.org](mailto:policy-resources@sans.org).  
> **Status**: **Retired** (Last Updated: December 2013)  
> © SANS Institute 2013 – All Rights Reserved

> ⚠️ **Note**: This policy has been **retired by SANS** but provides a strong foundation for modern acceptable use policies. Consider integrating its principles into a current **Acceptable Use Policy (AUP)** or **Secure Web Access Standard**.

---

## 1. Overview

Internet connectivity introduces significant risks to `<Company Name>`’s information assets, including:

- **Misuse of resources** (e.g., non-business browsing reducing productivity)  
- **Reputational harm** or **legal liability** from inappropriate use  
- **Exposure to inaccurate or malicious content** (the Internet has no quality control)

> 📌 **Guiding Principle**: Internet access is granted **only to support business activities** and on an **as-needed basis**.

> **Note**: Replace `<Company Name>` with your actual organization name when implementing.

---

## 2. Purpose

This policy defines **acceptable and prohibited uses** of the Internet by `<Company Name>` employees, contractors, and affiliates when using company computing or network resources.

---

## 3. Scope

Applies to **all users** accessing the Internet via `<Company Name>` resources, including:
- Full-time and part-time employees  
- Contractors, temporary workers, vendors, and business partners

All users must:
- Be familiar with this policy  
- Exercise **good judgment and common sense**  
- Understand that **monitoring occurs**

---

### 3.1 Internet Services Allowed

Internet access is **for business purposes only**. The following services are permitted **as needed**:

| Service | Permitted Use |
|--------|---------------|
| **Email** | Send/receive messages (with or without attachments) |
| **Web Browsing (HTTP/HTTPS)** | Access business-relevant websites; full outbound access, limited inbound to public web servers only |
| **File Transfer Protocol (FTP)** | Transfer files necessary for business |
| **Telnet** | Terminal emulation — **only with strong authentication** for inbound connections |

> 🔒 **All other Internet services are prohibited** unless explicitly approved by IT.

Management reserves the right to **add or remove services** based on business needs.

---

### 3.2 Request & Approval Procedures

#### 3.2.1 Request for Internet Access
- Users must **read and acknowledge** this policy and the **Internet/Intranet Security Policy**  
- **Signed acknowledgment** is required **before access is granted**

#### 3.2.2 Approval
- Submit an **IT Access Request Form** + **signed acknowledgment** to the IT Department  
- Manager approval required

#### 3.2.3 Removal of Privileges
Access will be revoked when:
- Employment or contract ends  
- Job role changes (new request required within 5 days)  
- Policy violation occurs  
- Account is **inactive for 30 days**  
- Annual review determines access is no longer needed

---

## 4. Policy

### 4.1 Resource Usage
- Access granted based on **current job responsibilities**  
- Departments must **periodically review** user access needs

### 4.2 Allowed Usage (Business Purposes Only)
Examples include:
- Business communication with external parties  
- Downloading software patches/upgrades  
- Researching vendors or products  
- Accessing regulatory or technical documentation

### 4.3 Personal Usage
- **Not permitted** without **explicit approval** from manager and IT  
- **Audit logs** track all activity (source/destination IPs, requests)  
- **Personal data** (credit cards, private keys, "wallets") transmitted at **user’s own risk**  
- `<Company Name>` is **not liable** for loss of personal information

### 4.4 Prohibited Usage

❌ **Strictly forbidden**:

- Accessing, storing, or sharing **illegal, pornographic, or discriminatory content**  
- Conducting **personal business**, **political activity**, or **gambling**  
- **Unauthorized access** to company data (e.g., customer records, HR files)  
- **Altering or disclosing** confidential information without authorization  
- **Linking company sites** to inappropriate external content  
- **Violating laws** (including export controls, copyright, libel)  
- **Downloading/shareware** without IT/manager approval  
- **Online shopping, gaming, chain letters, contests, or promotional gifts**

> 📉 **Bandwidth is a shared resource** — avoid activities that degrade performance for others.

### 4.5 Software License & Copyright
- **Strict compliance** with software license agreements required  
- **Assume all Internet content is copyrighted** unless stated otherwise  
- **"Fair use"** applies per international copyright law — when in doubt, **seek permission**

### 4.6 Review of Public Information
- All **publicly writable directories** on Internet-facing systems are **cleared nightly**  
- Prevents storage of **pirated content, passwords, credit card numbers, pornography**

### 4.7 Expectation of Privacy

#### 4.7.1 Monitoring
- **No expectation of privacy** on company systems  
- Management may **review emails, files, web history** at any time, without notice

#### 4.7.2 Email Confidentiality
- **Email is not secure or private**  
- Messages can be **forwarded, intercepted, altered, or stored indefinitely**  
- **Deletion from your device ≠ deletion from company systems**

### 4.8 Maintaining Corporate Image

#### 4.8.1 Representation
- When stating company affiliation online, include:  
  > *"Opinions expressed are my own and not necessarily those of `<Company Name>`."*

#### 4.8.2 Company Materials
- **Do not post** internal documents, press releases, or product info to public forums  
- All external postings require **manager + PR approval**

#### 4.8.3 Creating Websites
- All company websites require:
  - Business, implementation, and maintenance plans  
  - **Formal IT authorization**  
  - **Content review by Corporate Communications**  
  - **Security hardening** (via IT)

> 🏢 All company web properties are **owned and overseen by Corporate Communications**.

### 4.9 Periodic Reviews

- **Usage Compliance Reviews**: Ensure policy adherence  
- **Policy Maintenance Reviews**: Update policy as needed to reflect evolving risks and business needs

---

## 5. Policy Compliance

### 5.1 Compliance Measurement  
The Infosec team will verify compliance through:
- Web/email logs and DLP reports  
- Internal/external audits  
- Manager and user feedback

### 5.2 Exceptions  
All exceptions require **prior written approval** from the Infosec Team.

### 5.3 Non-Compliance  
Violations may result in:
- **Disciplinary action**, up to and including **termination**  
- **Legal action** for damages  
- **Mandatory reporting** to law enforcement for illegal activity

> ✍️ **Acknowledgment Required**: Internet access is **not granted** until the user and manager sign the **Internet Usage Acknowledgment Form** (see Section 6).

---

## 6. Internet Usage Coverage Acknowledgment Form

> **By signing below, you acknowledge that you have read, understood, and agree to comply with this policy.**

| Field | Value |
|------|-------|
| **Location** | _________________________________________ |
| **Business Purpose** | _________________________________________ |
| **Name** | _________________________________________ |
| **Signature** | _________________________   **Date**: _____________ |
| **Manager/Supervisor Signature** | _________________________   **Date**: _____________ |

> 📁 This form is filed in HR (employees) or IT (contractors) and subject to audit.

---

## 7. Definitions and Terms

While no definitions were listed in the original policy, the following terms are relevant:

| Term | Definition (per [SANS Glossary](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/)) |
|------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **Data Breach** | [A security incident in which sensitive information is accessed or disclosed without authorization.](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/#data-breach) |
| **Confidentiality** | [Ensuring information is disclosed only to authorized individuals.](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/#confidentiality) |
| **Due Care** | [Implementing a minimal level of protection per industry best practices.](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/#due-care) |

---

## 8. Revision History

| Date       | Responsible        | Summary of Change                     |
|------------|--------------------|----------------------------------------|
| Dec 2013   | SANS Policy Team   | Converted format and **retired**.      |

---

> **End of Policy**

---

## 1. Overview

See [Purpose](#2-purpose).

---

## 2. Purpose

To establish requirements for all computers connected to `<Company Name>` lab networks to ensure **effective virus detection and prevention**.

> **Note**: Replace `<Company Name>` with your actual organization name when implementing.

---

## 3. Scope

This policy applies to all **PC-based lab computers**, including but not limited to:
- Desktop and laptop computers  
- File, FTP, TFTP, and proxy servers  
- PC-based lab equipment (e.g., traffic generators, protocol analyzers)

> ❌ **Excluded**: Systems running **non-Microsoft operating systems** (e.g., Linux, macOS, embedded OS) are **currently exempt**, though this should be reevaluated as threats evolve.

---

## 4. Policy

- All covered lab computers **must have** `<Company Name>`’s **standard, supported anti-virus software** installed.  
- Anti-virus software **must be scheduled to run at regular intervals** (e.g., daily scans).  
- **Virus definition (pattern) files must be kept up-to-date**—ideally via automated updates.  
- Any computer **confirmed or suspected to be infected** must be:
  - **Immediately disconnected** from the network  
  - **Scanned and cleaned**  
  - **Verified as virus-free** before reconnection  

### Responsibilities
- **Lab Administrators / Lab Managers** are responsible for:
  - Creating and enforcing procedures to ensure regular anti-virus execution  
  - Verifying systems are clean before network reconnection  

### Prohibited Activities
- **Creating, testing, or distributing** malicious code (e.g., viruses, worms, Trojans, email bombs) is **strictly prohibited**, per the **[Acceptable Use Policy](#6-related-standards-policies-and-processes)**.

### Guidance
- Refer to `<Company Name>`’s **[Anti-Virus Recommended Processes](#6-related-standards-policies-and-processes)** for best practices in prevention and response.

---

## 5. Policy Compliance

### 5.1 Compliance Measurement  
The Infosec team will verify compliance through:
- Periodic lab walkthroughs  
- Endpoint security reports  
- Internal/external audits  
- Feedback from lab staff

### 5.2 Exceptions  
All exceptions require **prior written approval** from the Infosec team.

### 5.3 Non-Compliance  
Violations may result in:
- **Disciplinary action**, up to and including **termination of employment**  
- **Immediate revocation** of lab and network access

---

| Term | Definition (per [SANS Glossary](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/)) |
|------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **Virus** | A type of malware that replicates by inserting copies of itself into other programs or files. |
| **Worm** | A self-replicating malware that spreads across networks without user interaction. |
| **Trojan Horse** | Malware disguised as legitimate software to trick users into installing it. |
| **Malware** | Short for "malicious software"—any program designed to harm or exploit systems. |

> 🔗 Full definitions: [SANS Glossary of Terms](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/)

If you would like to contribute a new policy or updated version of this policy, please send email to [policy-resources@sans.org](mailto:policy-resources@sans.org).

---

## 1. Overview

Mobile devices (e.g., smartphones, tablets, laptops) enhance productivity and flexibility but also introduce significant risks of **data loss or theft**. To mitigate these risks, their use must align with security standards, and **encryption must be applied whenever possible**.

> **Note**: Replace `<Company Name>` with your actual organization name when implementing.

---

## 2. Purpose

This policy defines **Information Security requirements** for **encrypting data at rest** on all `<Company Name>` mobile devices.

---

## 3. Scope

Applies to **any mobile device** that:
- Is **issued by `<Company Name>`**, **or**  
- Is **used for `<Company Name>` business** and **stores `<Company Name>`-owned data**

> 📱 **Includes**: Laptops, smartphones, tablets, PDAs, and other portable computing devices.

---

## 4. Policy

- **All mobile devices storing `<Company Name>` data must use an approved encryption method** to protect **data at rest**.  
- **Storing `<Company Name>` data on non-issued personal devices is strictly prohibited** (e.g., company email on a personal phone).

### 4.1 Laptops
- Must use **full disk encryption (FDE)** with a **company-approved software solution** (e.g., BitLocker, FileVault, VeraCrypt).  
- **No `<Company Name>` data may exist in plaintext** on any laptop.

### 4.2 PDAs and Cell Phones
- All `<Company Name>` data must be stored in an **encrypted file system** using **approved software**.  
- `<Company Name>` **must deploy remote wipe capability** to **erase data** from lost or stolen devices.

### 4.3 Encryption Keys and Passphrases
- All keys and passphrases must comply with the **[Password Protection Policy](#6-related-standards-policies-and-processes)** (e.g., minimum length, complexity, rotation).

### 4.4 Loss and Theft
- **Immediate reporting** is required for **any lost or stolen device** containing `<Company Name>` data.  
- Upon report, IT/InfoSec will initiate **remote wipe** and **access revocation**.

---

## 5. Policy Compliance

### 5.1 Compliance Measurement  
The Infosec team will verify compliance through:
- MDM/UEM console reports  
- Internal/external audits  
- Endpoint configuration scans  
- User attestations

All exceptions require **prior written approval** from the Infosec Team.

Violations may result in:

- **Revocation** of mobile device privileges

# Pandemic Response Planning Policy

> **Free Use Disclaimer**: This policy was created by or for the SANS Institute for the Internet community. All or parts of this policy can be freely used for your organization. There is no prior approval required. If you would like to contribute a new policy or updated version of this policy, please send email to [policy-resources@sans.org](mailto:policy-resources@sans.org).  
> **Last Update Status**: Updated March 2020  
> © SANS Institute 2020 – All Rights Reserved

---

## 1. Overview

This policy is intended for organizations **not classified as critical infrastructure** under U.S. federal guidelines. During a pandemic, public health authorities may require offices to close to non-essential personnel—or entirely—to reduce disease transmission.

Unlike localized disasters (e.g., hurricanes, earthquakes), a **global pandemic** cannot be mitigated by failover to a backup site. Extended workforce unavailability threatens business continuity and financial viability. Proactive planning for **remote work**, **personnel resilience**, and **operational adaptation** is essential to organizational survival.

> **Note**: Replace `<Company Name>` with your actual organization name when implementing.

---

## 2. Purpose

This policy mandates **pandemic-specific planning** beyond standard Business Continuity (BCP) and Disaster Recovery (DRP) processes. It addresses the unique challenge that **a significant portion—or all—of the workforce may be unable to work on-site** due to illness, caregiving duties, or public health mandates.

---

## 3. Scope

- **Planning Phase**: Involves BCP/DRP teams, enterprise architects, and senior leadership of `<Company Name>`.  
- **Implementation Phase**: Applies to **all employees and contractors**, who must complete required training before and during an outbreak.

---

## 4. Policy

`<Company Name>` will **authorize, develop, and maintain** a Pandemic Response Plan addressing the following:

### 4.1 Leadership & Succession
- A **dedicated Pandemic Response Team** will lead plan development and updates.  
- The team must develop **internal expertise** on disease transmission, waves, and public health guidance.  
- **Trained alternates** must be designated for all leadership roles to ensure continuity if primary members become unavailable.

### 4.2 Communications Plan
- Develop a **resilient communication strategy** accounting for potential telecom congestion (e.g., SMS, email, collaboration tools, satellite phones).

### 4.3 Situational Awareness & Alerting
- Monitor authoritative sources for early warnings:
  - World Health Organization (WHO)  
  - Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)  
  - Federal, state, and local public health agencies

### 4.4 Emergency Policies (Tiered by Severity)
Predefined policies will **temporarily override standard operations** during a declared pandemic, scaled to disruption levels:

| Area | Policy Focus |
|------|-------------|
| **a) Payroll** | How employees will be compensated |
| **b) Work Location** | Remote work; allowances for childcare (e.g., bringing children to work if essential) |
| **c) Task Execution** | Tools and processes for remote productivity |
| **d) Suspended Activities** | Non-essential functions to pause |
| **e) Communication Cadence** | Frequency and channels for leadership updates |
| **f) Alternate Comms** | Backup methods if primary systems fail |
| **g) Operational Adjustments** | Changes to visitor policies, events, facilities access |

### 4.5 Response Triggers
- Define **clear indicators** (e.g., WHO Pandemic Phase, local infection rates) to activate response levels.  
- Ensure **graduated escalation** aligned with public health guidance.

### 4.6 Employee Health & Safety Training
All personnel must be trained on:
- **Symptoms** of exposure  
- Risks of **disease clusters** (schools, daycares, gatherings)  
- **Prevention**:  
  - Maintain 6+ feet distance  
  - Cover coughs/sneezes  
  - Frequent handwashing  
- **Stay-home protocols** (with encouragement, no penalty)  
- **Travel restrictions** to high-risk areas

### 4.7 High-Risk Employee Identification
- Identify staff with:  
  - Household members who are **first responders or medical personnel**  
  - **Single-parent status**  
- These individuals have higher risk of unavailability; plan accordingly.

### 4.8 Critical Role Continuity
- Map **key personnel** for each critical business function.  
- Establish **succession plans** and cross-training to ensure continuity if staff fall ill.

### 4.9 Essential Supplies
Maintain or pre-contract supplies including:
- Face masks, hand sanitizer  
- Fuel, food, and water (for essential on-site staff)  
- IT consumables (e.g., printer ink, cables)

### 4.10 IT Preparedness
- **Enterprise architects** must integrate pandemic scenarios into infrastructure planning.  
- Verify capacity for **mass remote work**:  
  - Bandwidth and VPN concentrator licensing  
  - VoIP and laptop/remote desktop availability  
- Expand use of **virtual meeting tools** (video, screen sharing)  
- Identify **tasks that cannot be done remotely**  
- Secure **vendor agreements** for emergency licensing flexibility  
- Define **on-site IT staffing needs** for critical systems  
- Plan for **altered customer interactions** (e.g., digital-only support)  
- Set clear expectations on:  
  - Printing work documents on **personal printers**  
  - Sending work files to **personal email accounts** (generally prohibited)

### 4.11 Plan Testing
- Conduct **regular exercises** (tabletop, simulation) to validate the plan.

### 4.12 Post-Exercise Review
- Perform **retrospectives** to identify gaps and implement improvements.

### 4.13 Plan Maintenance
- Review and update the plan **at least annually**.  
- Require **leadership sign-off** on all major revisions.

### 4.14 Audit Guidance
- Auditors must verify that **BCP, DRP, and enterprise architecture** reviews include assessment of alignment with this Pandemic Response Plan.

---

## 5. Policy Compliance

### 5.1 Compliance Measurement  
The Infosec team will verify compliance through:
- Plan documentation reviews  
- Exercise participation records  
- Internal/external audits  
- Leadership attestations

### 5.2 Exceptions  
All exceptions require **prior written approval** from **`<company leadership>`** and **annual revalidation**.

### 5.3 Non-Compliance  
Violations may result in:
- **Disciplinary action**, up to and including **termination of employment**

---

## 6. Related Standards, Policies and Processes

- [World Health Organization (WHO)](https://www.who.int/)  
- [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)](https://www.cdc.gov/)  
- **[Business Continuity Plan (BCP)](#)**  
- **[Disaster Recovery Plan (DRP)](#)**  
- **[Remote Work Policy](#)**

> *(Link to your organization’s internal policies as applicable.)*

---

## 7. Definitions and Terms

The following term is defined in the **[SANS Glossary of Terms](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/)**:

- **[Pandemic](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/#pandemic)**: *An epidemic occurring worldwide, or over a very wide area, crossing international boundaries and usually affecting a large number of people.*

---

# Password Construction Guidelines

> **Free Use Disclaimer**: This policy was created by or for the SANS Institute for the Internet community. All or parts of this policy can be freely used for your organization. There is no prior approval required. If you would like to contribute a new policy or updated version of this policy, please send email to [policy-resources@sans.org](mailto:policy-resources@sans.org).  
> **Last Update Status**: Updated October 2017  
> © SANS Institute 2017 – All Rights Reserved

---

## 1. Overview

Passwords are a **critical component of information security**. They protect user accounts—but a **poorly constructed password** can lead to the compromise of systems, data, or entire networks.  
This guideline provides **modern, evidence-based best practices** for creating **strong, usable, and secure passwords**.

---

## 2. Purpose

To establish **best practices for creating strong passwords** that balance **security** and **usability**, in alignment with current standards such as **NIST SP 800-63-3**.

---

## 3. Scope

Applies to:
- All **employees, contractors, consultants, temporary workers**, and third-party personnel  
- All **password-protected systems**, including:
  - User and system-level accounts  
  - Web and email accounts  
  - Screen savers  
  - Voicemail  
  - Local router and device logins

---

## 4. Statement of Guidelines

### ✅ **Strong Passwords**
- **Minimum length**: **14 characters**  
- **Strongly encouraged**: Use **passphrases** (multiple random or meaningful words)  
  - Examples:  
    - `It’s time for vacation`  
    - `block-curious-sunny-leaves`  
    - `PurpleTiger$RunsFast!`
- Passphrases are **easy to remember**, **easy to type**, and **highly resistant to brute-force attacks**

### ❌ **Weak Passwords (Prohibited)**
Avoid passwords that:
- Are **8 characters or fewer**  
- Contain **personal information**:  
  - Names (family, pets, friends, fictional characters)  
  - Birthdates, addresses, phone numbers  
- Use **predictable patterns**:  
  - `qwerty`, `123456`, `aaabbb`, `zyxwvuts`, `123321`  
- Are common defaults or variants:  
  - `Password123`, `Welcome123`, `Changeme123`, `Admin!2023`

### 🔐 **Additional Requirements**
- **Every work account must have a unique password**  
- **Use an organization-approved password manager** to securely store and manage multiple credentials  
- **Enable multi-factor authentication (MFA)** wherever possible

> 📌 **Note**: Per **NIST SP 800-63-3**, password complexity rules (e.g., mandatory symbols, mixed case) are **less important than length**. Focus on **length and unpredictability** over forced character variety.

---

## 5. Policy Compliance

### 5.1 Compliance Measurement  
The Infosec team will verify compliance through:
- Password policy enforcement in identity systems (e.g., Active Directory, IAM)  
- Internal/external audits  
- Security tool reports (e.g., password cracking tests, MFA adoption metrics)

### 5.2 Exceptions  
All exceptions require **prior written approval** from the Infosec team.

### 5.3 Non-Compliance  
Violations may result in:
- **Disciplinary action**, up to and including **termination of employment**  
- **Account lockout** or forced password reset

---

## 6. Related Standards, Policies and Processes

- **[Password Policy](#)**  
- **[Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) Policy](#)**  
- **[Acceptable Use Policy](#)**  
- **NIST Special Publication 800-63-3**: *Digital Identity Guidelines*

---

## 7. Definitions and Terms

While no definitions were listed in the original document, the following terms are relevant:

| Term | Definition (per [SANS Glossary](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/)) |
|------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **Passphrase** | A sequence of words or other text used to control access to a system, typically longer and more secure than a password. |
| **Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)** | Authentication using two or more factors: something you know (password), something you have (token), something you are (biometric). |
| **Brute-Force Attack** | An attack that tries all possible password combinations until the correct one is found. |

> 🔗 Full definitions: [SANS Glossary of Terms](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/)

---

| Date | Responsible | Summary of Change |
|------|-------------|-------------------|
| June 2014 | SANS Policy Team | Separated from the Password Policy and converted to new format. |
| October 2017 | SANS Policy Team | Updated to reflect changes in **NIST SP 800-63-3** (e.g., emphasis on length over complexity, elimination of forced periodic resets). |

---

> **End of Guidelines**

content:
# Password Protection Policy

> **Free Use Disclaimer**: This policy was created by or for the SANS Institute for the Internet community. All or parts of this policy can be freely used for your organization. There is no prior approval required. If you would like to contribute a new policy or updated version of this policy, please send email to [policy-resources@sans.org](mailto:policy-resources@sans.org).  
> **Last Update Status**: Updated October 2017  
> © SANS Institute 2017 – All Rights Reserved

---

## 1. Overview

Passwords are a **critical component of computer security**. A poorly chosen or mishandled password can lead to **unauthorized access**, **data breaches**, and **exploitation of company resources**.  

All personnel—including employees, contractors, and vendors—with access to `<Company Name>` systems are responsible for **creating strong passwords** and **protecting them appropriately**.

> **Note**: Replace `<Company Name>` with your actual organization name when implementing.

---

## 2. Purpose

To establish a **standard for the creation, management, and protection** of passwords across all `<Company Name>` systems and accounts.

---

## 3. Scope

This policy applies to **all personnel** who:
- Have or manage an account (or any password-protected access) on any system that:
  - Resides at a `<Company Name>` facility  
  - Connects to the `<Company Name>` network  
  - Stores **non-public `<Company Name>` information**

> 📌 Includes: user accounts, service accounts, privileged accounts, web logins, database credentials, and more.

---

## 4. Policy

### 4.1 Password Creation

- **4.1.1** All passwords must comply with the **[Password Construction Guidelines](#6-related-standards-policies-and-processes)** (e.g., minimum 14 characters, use of passphrases).
- **4.1.2** Users **must use a unique password for each work-related account**.  
  ❌ **Never reuse work passwords for personal accounts**.
- **4.1.3** Accounts with **system-level privileges** (e.g., via `sudo`, admin groups) **must have a unique password** separate from the user’s standard account.  
  ✅ **Multi-factor authentication (MFA) is strongly recommended for all privileged accounts**.

### 4.2 Password Change

- **4.2.1** Passwords **should only be changed if compromise is suspected**—**not on a fixed schedule** (per NIST SP 800-63-3).
- **4.2.2** The Infosec Team may perform **periodic or random password cracking tests**.  
  - If a password is cracked, the user **must immediately change it** to meet **Password Construction Guidelines**.

### 4.3 Password Protection

- **4.3.1** **Never share passwords**—not with coworkers, supervisors, or IT staff.  
  > All passwords are **Confidential `<Company Name>` information**.
- **4.3.2** **Never transmit passwords** via:
  - Email  
  - Chat (e.g., Teams, Slack)  
  - Phone calls  
  - Ticketing systems (e.g., "Alliance cases")
- **4.3.3** Passwords may **only be stored** in **organization-approved password managers** (e.g., 1Password, Bitwarden, Keeper).
- **4.3.4** **Disable "Remember Password"** features in browsers and applications.
- **4.3.5** If a password **may be compromised**, the user must:
  - **Report the incident** to Infosec  
  - **Change all affected passwords immediately**

### 4.4 Application Development Requirements

All internally developed or procured applications must:
- **4.4.1** Support **individual user authentication** (not shared/group logins)
- **4.4.2** **Never store passwords** in **plaintext** or **reversible formats** (use strong hashing: Argon2, bcrypt, scrypt)
- **4.4.3** **Never transmit passwords** in **plaintext** over the network (use TLS 1.2+)
- **4.4.4** Support **role-based delegation** so users can assume functions **without sharing passwords**

### 4.5 Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)

- **4.5.1** MFA is **highly encouraged** for **all work accounts** and **personal accounts** (e.g., email, cloud storage).  
- MFA is **required** for:
  - Remote access  
  - Privileged accounts  
  - Access to sensitive data

---

## 5. Policy Compliance

### 5.1 Compliance Measurement  
The Infosec team will verify compliance through:
- Identity and access management (IAM) system audits  
- Password cracking exercises  
- Application security reviews  
- Internal/external audits

### 5.2 Exceptions  
All exceptions require **prior written approval** from the Infosec Team.

### 5.3 Non-Compliance  
Violations may result in:
- **Disciplinary action**, up to and including **termination of employment**  
- **Immediate revocation** of system access

---

## 6. Related Standards, Policies and Processes

- **[Password Construction Guidelines](#)**  
- **[Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) Policy](#)**  
- **[Acceptable Use Policy](#)**  
- **NIST Special Publication 800-63-3**: *Digital Identity Guidelines*

---

## 7. Definitions and Terms

| Term | Definition (per [SANS Glossary](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/)) |
|------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **Password** | A secret string of characters used to authenticate a user. |
| **Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)** | Authentication using two or more factors: something you know, have, or are. |
| **Confidential Information** | Data that must be protected from unauthorized access (e.g., PII, financial records). |

> 🔗 Full definitions: [SANS Glossary of Terms](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/)

> 📱 **PCDs include**:  
> - Cellular phones  
> - Handheld wireless devices (e.g., smartphones, tablets)  
> - Laptop wireless cards  
> - Pagers

---

## 4. Policy

### 4.1 Issuing Policy
- PCDs are issued **only to personnel** whose duties require **immediate and frequent contact** while away from their normal work location.  
- Distribution must be **cost-justified** by productivity gains.  
- **Handheld wireless devices** may be issued to **executive and management staff** who need to:
  - Conduct **immediate, critical business**  
  - **Review and respond** to issues with documented actions

### 4.2 Bluetooth
- **Hands-free devices (e.g., Bluetooth)** may be issued to **approved personnel**.  
- **Security caution**:  
  - Avoid pairing in public or insecure areas  
  - Note: **Bluetooth 2.0 Class 1** devices have a **range of up to 330 feet**—increasing eavesdropping risk

### 4.3 Voicemail
- Voicemail boxes may be issued to personnel who need a **message-receiving capability** when unavailable.  
- **All voicemail boxes must be protected by a PIN** that:  
  - ❌ **Is not the last four digits** of the associated phone number  
  - ✅ Meets complexity requirements (if defined in Password Policy)

### 4.4 Loss and Theft
- **Confidential or sensitive data** may **only be stored** on PCDs if protected by **company-approved encryption**.  
- ❌ **Never store confidential data** on **personal PCDs**.  
- **Lost or stolen devices must be reported immediately** to IT/InfoSec.  
- **Employees may be held financially responsible** for:  
  - Repair costs due to **misuse**  
  - Costs of **non-standard equipment**

### 4.5 Personal Use
- PCDs and voicemail are issued for **`<Company Name>` business**.  
- **Personal use must be minimal and incidental** (e.g., brief personal calls).

### 4.6 PCD Safety
- **Using PCDs while driving is a safety hazard**.  
- Employees must:  
  - **Park or exit the vehicle** before use, **or**  
  - Use **hands-free enabling devices** if driving is unavoidable  
- Comply with all **local distracted driving laws**

- Internal/external assessments

# Consensus Policy Resource Community  
## Remote Access Policy  

---

### 1. Overview  
Remote access to our corporate network is essential to maintain our team’s productivity. However, in many cases this remote access originates from networks that may already be compromised or have a lower security posture than our corporate network. While these networks are beyond the control of <Company Name>, we must mitigate these risks to the best of our ability.  

---

### 2. Purpose  
This policy defines rules and requirements for connecting to <Company Name>'s network from any host. These rules are designed to minimize potential exposure from unauthorized use of <Company Name> resources.  

Damages may include:  
- Loss of sensitive or confidential data  
- Loss of intellectual property  
- Damage to public image  
- Damage to critical internal systems  
- Fines or financial liabilities  

---

### 3. Scope  
This policy applies to:  
- All <Company Name> employees, contractors, vendors, and agents  
- Both <Company Name>-owned and personally-owned devices used for remote access  
- All remote access connections used to perform work for <Company Name> (e.g., email, intranet, applications)  

This policy covers **all technical implementations of remote access**.  

---

### 4. Policy  

Employees, contractors, vendors, and agents with remote access privileges are responsible for ensuring their connection is as secure as an on-site connection.  

- Internet access for recreational use through the <Company Name> network is restricted to **Authorized Users**.  
- Authorized Users are responsible for preventing access to company resources by non-Authorized Users.  
- Illegal activities on the network are prohibited.  
- Authorized Users bear responsibility for misuse of their access.  
- Company networks must not be used to pursue outside business interests.  

Additional details on access options, login credentials, anti-virus software, and troubleshooting can be found on the **Remote Access Services website** (insert company URL).  

---

#### 4.1 Requirements  

1. **Encryption & Authentication**  
   - Secure remote access must use encryption (e.g., VPNs) and strong passphrases.  
   - Refer to the **Acceptable Encryption Policy** and **Password Policy**.  

2. **Login & Password Protection**  
   - Credentials must be protected and not shared, even with family.  

3. **Device Restrictions**  
   - While using a company-owned device for remote access, it must not be connected to any other network at the same time (except personal networks under complete control of the Authorized User or approved third parties).  

4. **External Resources**  
   - Use of third-party/external resources for company business must be approved in advance by **InfoSec** and the business unit manager.  

5. **Anti-Virus Requirements**  
   - All hosts connecting remotely must use the most up-to-date anti-virus software.  
   - This applies to personal computers and third-party connections (per **Third Party Agreement**).  

6. **Personal Equipment**  
   - Personal equipment must meet the same standards as company-owned equipment (see **Hardware & Software Configuration Standards for Remote Access**).  

---

### 5. Policy Compliance  

**5.1 Compliance Measurement**  
- The InfoSec Team will verify compliance through audits, monitoring, reporting, and inspections.  

**5.2 Exceptions**  
- Exceptions must be approved in advance by Remote Access Services and InfoSec.  

**5.3 Non-Compliance**  
- Employees found violating this policy may face disciplinary action, up to and including termination.

Remote desktop software (remote access tools) enables users and IT support staff to share screens, access work systems from home, and collaborate efficiently.

While these tools save time and money, they also create potential back doors into <Company Name> systems. Improper use could result in:

- Theft of information  
- System compromise or destruction

### 2. Purpose  
This policy defines the requirements for remote access tools used within <Company Name>.  

---

This policy applies to **all remote access connections** where either end of the communication terminates at a <Company Name> asset.

- <Company Name> provides mechanisms for collaboration between employees, external partners, and remote systems.  
- The **approved software list** is available at: `<link-to-approved-remote-access-software-list>`.  
- Mandatory **configuration procedures** are provided for each approved tool to ensure secure setup.

- All mobile devices and storage devices containing or accessing company information must be **approved prior to connecting** to <Company Name> systems.

Laptops, PDAs, USB drives, CDs, DVDs, flash drives, modems, handheld wireless devices, wireless cards, and future portable devices.

---

### 1. Overview  
A **Security Response Plan (SRP)** ensures that security and business teams:  
- Work together effectively on awareness and communication  
- Coordinate response efforts in times of crisis (e.g., identified or exploited vulnerabilities)  

An SRP must define:  
- Service/product description  
- Contact information  
- Escalation paths  
- Service Level Agreements (SLAs)  
- Severity & impact classification  
- Mitigation & remediation timelines  

By integrating SRPs into business continuity operations and new service/product rollouts, organizations can **swiftly mitigate and remediate incidents**.  

---

### 2. Purpose  
The purpose of this policy is to ensure **all business units supported by the Infosec team** develop and maintain a **Security Response Plan (SRP)**.  
This guarantees that the Security Incident Management Team has the necessary information to formulate a successful response when incidents occur.  

---

### 3. Scope  
This policy applies to **all established and defined business units or entities within <Company Name>**.  

---

### 4. Policy  

The development, implementation, and execution of SRPs are the responsibility of the **business unit**, in cooperation with the **Infosec team**.  

#### 4.1 Service or Product Description  
Each SRP must clearly define:  
- The service or application to be deployed  
- Data flows  
- Logical diagrams  
- Architecture documentation  

#### 4.2 Contact Information  
Each SRP must include **dedicated contact information** (phone & email) for team members available **outside of business hours**.  
- May require 24/7 coverage based on business impact and customer needs  

#### 4.3 Triage  
Each SRP must define **triage steps** coordinated with the Security Incident Management Team, including:  
- Validation of reported vulnerabilities or compromises  
- Initial response actions  

#### 4.4 Identified Mitigations and Testing  
Each SRP must define processes for:  
- Identifying mitigations  
- Testing mitigations prior to deployment  
- Including both **short-term mitigations** and **long-term remediation**  

#### 4.5 Mitigation and Remediation Timelines  
SRPs must define **response timelines** based on:  
- Severity of vulnerability  
- Impact on customer, brand, and company  

Response guidelines should map to severity levels for reported vulnerabilities.  

---

### 5. Policy Compliance  

#### 5.1 Compliance Measurement  
- Each business unit must demonstrate they have a **written SRP** in place.  
- SRPs must be under **version control** and available via the web.  
- Policy must be reviewed **annually**.  

#### 5.2 Exceptions  
Any exception must be:  
- Approved in advance by the **Infosec Team**  
- Documented in writing

- Business units without SRPs may face **delays in service/product releases** until SRP approval.

## 1. Purpose  
The purpose of this policy is to ensure that all servers within **<Company Name>** are configured, managed, and audited in accordance with company security standards and applicable regulatory requirements. Regular audits help safeguard the **confidentiality, integrity, and availability** of company information and resources.  

---

## 2. Scope

- All servers owned, managed, or operated by **<Company Name>**.  
- Any third-party servers hosted on **<Company Name>** premises or connected to company networks.  

---

## 3. Policy  

### 3.1 Audit Requirements  
- All servers must be audited at least **annually** or more frequently if required by regulations or business needs.  
- Audits shall assess compliance with company security policies and detect vulnerabilities.  

### 3.2 Security Configuration Guidelines  
Servers must follow standard baseline configurations approved by the **Change Control Board (CCB)**, including:  
- Forwarding of all system logs to a central log management system.  
- Logging of all administrative (root/sudo) actions.  
- Use of a centralized patch management system.  
- Installation and regular updates of host security agents (e.g., antivirus, EDR).  
- Restriction of network ports and services to business requirements only.  
- Regular verification of administrative group memberships.  
- Conducting baselines during initial deployment and after major system changes.

## 1. Overview  
Unsecured servers continue to be a major entry point for malicious threat actors. Consistent server installation policies, ownership, and configuration management are key to minimizing risks.  

---

## 2. Purpose  
Establish standards for the base configuration of internal server equipment owned or operated by **<Company Name>**. Implementation of this policy minimizes unauthorized access to proprietary information and technology.

This policy applies to:  
- All employees, contractors, consultants, temporary and other workers at **<Company Name>** and its subsidiaries.  
- Server equipment owned, operated, or leased by **<Company Name>**, or registered under a **<Company Name>** internal network domain.  

> For secure configuration of equipment external to **<Company Name>** on the DMZ, see the Internet DMZ Equipment Policy.

## 4. Policy  

### 4.1 General Requirements  
1. All internal servers must be owned by an operational group responsible for system administration.  
2. Approved server configuration guides must be maintained by operational groups and approved by InfoSec.  
3. Operational groups must monitor configuration compliance and implement tailored exception policies.  
4. Required registration information in the corporate enterprise management system:  
   - Server contact(s), location, and backup contact  
   - Hardware and Operating System/Version  
   - Main functions and applications (if applicable)  
5. Information must be kept up-to-date.  
6. Configuration changes must follow change management procedures.  
7. Authorized personnel may monitor and audit equipment, systems, processes, and network traffic per the Audit Policy.  

### 4.2 Configuration Requirements  
1. OS configuration must comply with approved InfoSec guidelines.  
2. Unused services and applications must be disabled where practical.  
3. Access should be logged and/or protected through access-control methods such as web application firewalls.  
4. Apply security patches as soon as practical; exceptions allowed if business requirements conflict.  
5. Avoid trust relationships between systems unless necessary.  
6. Follow the principle of least privilege.  
7. Privileged access must use secure channels (e.g., SSH, IPSec) if available.  
8. Servers should be located in access-controlled environments; cubicles are prohibited.  

### 4.3 Monitoring  
1. Security-related events on critical or sensitive systems must be logged and audit trails saved:  
   - Online logs: 1 week  
   - Daily incremental tape backups: 1 month  
   - Weekly full tape backups: 1 month  
   - Monthly full backups: 2 years  
2. Security-related events must be reported to InfoSec for review and corrective actions. Examples include:  
   - Port-scan attacks

   - Anomalous occurrences not related to host applications

Applies to any computer/technology equipment or peripheral devices no longer needed, including:  
- Personal computers, servers, laptops, mainframes, smartphones, handheld computers

- Compact and floppy discs, portable storage devices (USB drives), backup tapes, printed materials

---

## 4. Policy

### 4.1 Technology Equipment Disposal
1. End-of-life technology assets should be sent to the **<Equipment Disposal Team>** office.  
2. The **<Equipment Disposal Team>** will securely erase all storage media using industry best practices.  
3. Data and licensed software shall be removed using disk sanitizing software that overwrites every disk sector with zero-filled blocks (DoD standard).

9. Non-functioning memory or storage devices must be removed and physically destroyed.

4. Finance and IT will set appropriate costs.

6. Remaining or non-working equipment will be donated or disposed of per environmental guidelines.

---

## 2. Purpose
This standard specifies the technical requirements that wireless infrastructure devices must satisfy to connect to a **<Company Name>** network.  
- Only devices meeting this standard or granted an exception by InfoSec are approved for network connectivity.  
- Network devices (hubs, routers, switches, firewalls, remote access devices, modems, wireless APs) must be installed, supported, and maintained by an Infosec-approved organization.  
- Lab network devices must comply with the **Lab Security Policy**.  

---

## 3. Scope
Applies to all employees, contractors, consultants, temporary staff, and personnel maintaining wireless infrastructure devices for **<Company Name>** and subsidiaries.  
- Covers devices that connect to the network or provide wireless connectivity.  
- Infosec must approve any exceptions in advance.  

---

## 4. Standard

### 4.1 General Requirements
Wireless devices connecting to the network or handling confidential/restricted information must:  
- Use one of the following authentication protocols:  
  - EAP-FAST (Extensible Authentication Protocol-Fast Authentication via Secure Tunneling)  
  - PEAP (Protected Extensible Authentication Protocol)  
  - EAP-TLS (Extensible Authentication Protocol-Transport Layer Security)  
- Use TKIP or AES encryption protocols with a minimum key length of 128 bits  
- Bluetooth devices must use Secure Simple Pairing with encryption enabled  

### 4.2 Lab and Isolated Wireless Device Requirements
- Lab device SSID must be different from production SSID  
- SSID broadcast must be disabled  

### 4.3 Home Wireless Device Requirements
Home devices providing direct access to **<Company Name>** networks (e.g., behind ECT or hardware VPN) must:  
- Enable WPA-PSK, EAP-FAST, PEAP, or EAP-TLS  
- Configure a complex shared secret key (minimum 20 characters) for WPA-PSK  
- Disable SSID broadcast

## 2. Purpose
To provide guidance for workstation security at **<Company Name>** to ensure:  
- The security of information on workstations  
- Compliance with HIPAA Security Rule “Workstation Security” Standard 164.310(c)  

---

## 3. Scope
Applies to all **<Company Name>** employees, contractors, workforce members, vendors, and agents using company-owned or personal workstations connected to the **<Company Name>** network.  

---

## 4. Policy
Workstations must be used in a manner that ensures confidentiality, integrity, and availability of sensitive information, including PHI. Access to sensitive data must be restricted to authorized users.

### 4.1 Workforce Responsibilities
- Consider sensitivity of information (PHI) and minimize unauthorized access  
- Implement physical and technical safeguards for all workstations accessing electronic PHI  

### 4.2 Appropriate Measures Include:
- Restrict physical access to authorized personnel only  
- Lock or log out of workstations when leaving the area  
- Enable password-protected screen saver with a short timeout  
- Follow **<Company Name> Password Policy**  
- Use workstations only for authorized business purposes  
- Never install unauthorized software  
- Store all sensitive data, including PHI, on network servers  
- Keep food and drinks away from workstations  
- Secure laptops with cable locks or store in locked cabinets  
- Comply with **Portable Workstation Encryption Policy**  
- Follow **Baseline Workstation Configuration Standard**  
- Use privacy screen filters or other physical barriers  
- Leave workstations on but logged off for after-hours updates  
- Exit running applications and close open documents before leaving  
- Ensure workstations use surge protectors or UPS (battery backup)  
- Secure wireless network access per **Wireless Communication Policy**

- Video monitoring  
- Business tool reports  
- Internal/external audits

### 5.3 Non-Compliance
